SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate of the sudden death on 9 November of Leonid Brezhnev, President of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Australia was represented at the funeral of the late President Brezhnev in Moscow on 15 November by the former Governor-General, Sir Zelman Cowen, accompanied by the Australian Ambassor to the Soviet Union, Mr Evans. In Australia President Brezhnev's death was marked by the normal practice of flying flags at half mast from public buildings on the day of the funeral. On 13 November the Acting Prime Minister ( Mr Anthony), on behalf of the Government, signed the condolence book at the Soviet Embassy in Canberra. His Excellency the Governor-General and the Acting Prime Minister sent condolence messages to the Deputy Chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet and to the Chairman of the Council of Ministers of the USSR.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the Press statements issued by the Acting Prime Minister on 11 November and by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) the following day. I do not wish to elaborate upon those statements and I believe it is too early to offer conclusive judgments about the policies likely to be followed by new leaders in Moscow, including Mr Andropov, who succeeds Mr Brezhnev as Secretary-General of the Soviet Communist Party. In the short term at least it seems that there will be continuity of leadership and of policies well known to us. But the Government hopes that the new leadership of the Soviet Union by its future actions will commit itself to genuine co-operation with the West and to the removal of current obstacles to a constructive relationship between Australia and the Soviet Union.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to associate the Opposition with the expressions of regret that the Government has made about the death of President Brezhnev of the Soviet Union. I do not wish to add much to what has been said by the Government except to say that President Brezhnev presided over the affairs of the Soviet Union for some 18 years. To attain the office of President and Secretary of the Communist Party in the Soviet Union is a great and rare achievement. To retain it for 18 years is perhaps an achievement of even greater memorability-if I may use that expression. All we would like to say is that through 18 very difficult years in international affairs and affairs in which the Soviet Union was intimately involved-in its relationships with both the West and China-President Brezhnev seemed to be a person who had a great capacity to keep his cool, given the very difficult circumstances in which the Soviet Government saw itself in its relationship with other countries. If that analysis is correct, it is a source of gratitude within the world that somebody of that temperament was in charge of the affairs of the Soviet Union through that period. We associate ourselves with the Government's response to the President's death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I understand there is no normal motion of condolence before the Chair. Therefore, I thank the Senate for giving me leave to make some observations about the life and works of this person, Leonid Brezhnev. Brezhnev presided over the Soviet Union with ruthless and relentless power for 18 years, between 1964 and 1982. Repression was a basic tool of his government. All opposition was suppressed. Dissidents were treated subhumanely and expelled, and one can look to Solzhenitsyn and Sakharov, to mention two of many. Minorities had almost all human rights arbitrarily withdrawn. The treatment of Soviet Jews is something to be condemned, not just their repression but the despicable fact that many of them were not able to leave the Soviet Union even though they wished to. According to human rights investigations, four million people in the Soviet Union today are undergoing forced labour under the regime of this man and at least another 10,000 people are political prisoners.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps one of the most deplorable and disgusting acts of this man and his colleagues was to gaol a man called Raoul Wallenberg, who has been incarcerated in Soviet psychiatric hospitals for 20 years. I will not refer to the foreign policy excursions initiated under this man. Let me conclude by saying for the record that it is a quaint habit we have in this place that when someone dies we look for good things or some things to say about them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a reasonable attitude to be taking.
—I do not take it.
—Then let it be on your own head.

—Let Senator Georges be more charitable than me. If someone performs in a way which helps his or her fellow human beings, then let that be recorded. But when someone rules with the power that this man had and brings so much agony and misery to his fellow human beings, let that also be recorded; and I so do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It is a matter of great regret that the Senate is not at the moment speaking to a motion of condolence.
—We would not carry it.

—For that reason, responding to the interjection, it would be advisable for us to know, as the interjector implied, that the motion of condolence would not be carried. That would be a further mark of discredit to the Senate. I am astonished that the Senate should descend to so mean a level as it has, by way of comment and interjection, that on the death of a person we should enter into political criticism, criticism which would be subject to question in an ordinary debate.

SPEECH.PARA: But let me move away from that and merely say some words in support of a person who has died. The Brisbane Courier-Mail, not the most radical of newspapers, had a headline concerning the late President Brezhnev, citing him as 'a calming voice in a volatile world'. In fact, on cool consideration of the matter, that is what Brezhnev was, a calming voice in a very volatile world. We are now entering into a period of great uncertainty. That uncertainty should concern us all. That uncertainty ought not to be added to by speeches such as the one by the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Chipp). When the great die the repercussions are considerable. The death of Brezhnev should make us listen and understand with greater concern than has been expressed in this place.

My impression of Brezhnev is that he was a calming voice in a volatile world. In fact, historians will indicate that it was he and his advice that led the world from the brink of war at the time of the Cuban crisis. For that and that alone he should be given great credit. My interpretation from time to time of Brezhnev's speeches was that he sought in his own way peace and detente. In many ways he succeeded. If Brezhnev made decisions which led to the death of other people, it was because of a grim responsibility which heads of state have to bear. It is a grim responsibility that Thatcher had to bear in relation to the Falkland Islands and that Begin had to bear in relation to Lebanon. It was a grim responsibility that Menzies had to face when he committed men to Vietnam and that Whitlam had to face when he considered the crisis in Timor. Although we do not condone that, we should understand that responsibility. If we were to follow the theme that this Senate wishes to follow today the future of the world would be uncertain. In case honourable senators have other ideas, I remind them that Vice-President Bush said:

We have come to declare to the Soviet leaders (and) to the Soviet people . . . that the United States is devoted to the pursuit of peace and a reduction of global tensions. We seek a world of greater harmony, not only between the two great superpowers, but for all nations. It is our fervent hope that today's massive expenditures for arms can be reduced and that the world's standard of living, especially for the impoverished, can be greatly improved.
Fears, suspicions and distrust must be replaced by hope, by trust, by mutual co -operation. The barriers that now divide nations and regions can be dismantled and discarded.
This spirit of hope . . . is with us all.

This spirit of hope was with me until this debate started today in the Senate. Having listened to Senator Chipp and interjections, I believe that the achievement of this spirit of hope is now questionable. If this is the way in which this spirit is being expressed, we are in serious trouble. Getting back to Brezhnev, it is to be hoped that all the good for which Brezhnev stood will live after him. I trust that that will be so.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On an occasion such as this it is usual for the Senate to hear from the leaders of the major parties. I would have left it at that but for various interjections and statements that flowed in response to what Senator Georges was just saying. I believe that all honourable senators care about the death of every individual in the world and that we all have a natural sympathy for anyone who dies. But Senator Georges should not have built upon that natural sympathy to make the remarks that he just made which I believe are not representative of the Senate. I believe that Senator Chipp's words summarise fairly and accurately the views of the majority of honourable senators from all parties. We should not run away at a time like this from recognising that a tyrant has ruled in a major country of the world. We have had debates in the Senate about Czechoslovakia, about Afghanistan, about Poland and about civil rights in the Soviet Union. At this time are we to deny the conclusions that have been reached in the Senate on those matters? I think former Senator John Wheeldon would have spoken most clearly and crisply on behalf of all of us if he had been here today. He put down a parliamentary report on human rights in the Soviet Union which shows that there is enormous tragedy in that country which developed during the time of this man's leadership . There will not be a vote on this matter in the Senate, but let it not pass that in my mind, at least, I believe Senator Chipp has spoken accurately for all of us.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Prime Minister. I refer to the call by the Acting Prime Minister for a wages pause to make available some $700m to be spent on a capital works program to counter unemployment. I ask: Did the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations say last week that each $1m spent on capital works programs of that kind generates only 25 jobs? At that rate, would the $700m generate only 17,500 jobs? As present job loss or disemployment is running at the rate of 1,000 jobs a day, would 17,500 jobs be lost elsewhere at the expiration of 17 1/2 days?

QUESTION.PARA: Questions without Notice

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a misunderstanding of the Government's policy announcement to draw such conclusions. I do not say that in a negative sense. The fact is that the Government is facing a situation in which high wages, particularly the wage rises in the last year, have caused huge rises in costs compared with other competing countries and have resulted in unemployment. The costs themselves are, in their true nature, the costs of labour; that is, the cost of wages. The main thrust to get down interest rates is to bear down on inflation. To bear down on inflation one must bear down upon on the fundamental ingredient of inflation, which is wage costs.
—It has been a long labour. You are still bearing down after seven years.

—Despite the interjections of the Opposition, the fact is that every other country in the free world facing this situation in a world- wide recession has come to the conclusion that the primary task is to bring about a condition of major wage restraint. Every other country in the free world has so comported itself that there has been substantial wage restraint including , in some cases, a lowering of wages. The aim of the Government is primarily to reduce costs so as to reduce inflation and, by so doing, to give future opportunities in Australia-as the recession moves away in the world-for Australian industries to take their opportunities to move outwards in greater job creation in the natural sense of recovery. The primary objective is to beat inflation, and in beating inflation create opportunities for more healthy jobs, and to reduce interest rates.

ANSWER.PARA: It is equally a misunderstanding to look at the question of job creation in this context. It is true that a Labor Minister of old said that one man's wage increase was another man's job. The Opposition runs away from that now. The fact of the matter is that if we can get wage restraint, if we can get a wage freeze, we can stop further major drifts of disemployment. That is devoutly hoped. To use a figure of $700m is to fail to understand the situation. The Government's aim is that the wage freeze should be not only in the Commonwealth, State and local government areas but throughout the community. Taken throughout the community this would in fact result in several billion dollars at least of wage savings. Put in its context, the figuring Senator Button has done is quite inaccurate. The Government is aiming to get the inflation rate down so that jobs can be created for the future as the world moves out of recession.

The Government is asking that there should be wage restraint throughout the whole community so there is no need for further disemployment, so there is a reduction of losses in industry, so there is not a collapse of industry and so that profitability returns and, therefore, job creation can be further developed . This principle has been adopted by virtually every country in the free world. The countries in the free world have all borne down on wages to get their inflation down and have got their inflation down below that of Australia. Unless we can get our inflation into a competitive condition with other countries, when the recovery commences we will be at a disadvantage. We do not intend to be so.

—I ask the Minister representing the Acting Prime Minister: When the Acting Prime Minister consults with the Premiers, on the date which has been announced, will he also put to the Premiers that not only wages ought to be frozen-a rather questionable proposition-but also prices and rents ought to be frozen and a moratorium on loans ought to be imposed? Will the Leader of the Government give some explanation to the Senate as to how it proposes that this initiative will succeed unless these other measures are also taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me take up this question because I think it is a serious one that requires a detailed answer. Firstly, as I have said in a previous answer, the ingredients of all costs in the end are the costs of labour that go towards making a particular material or providing a particular service. In the end the cost of labour is the vital factor in creating high costs and therefore high inflation. Consequently, the Commonwealth Government is seeking wage restraint. It is competent for any State government that so desires-the States have the powers; the Commonwealth does not-to do all those other things that Senator Georges mentioned. If State governments desire to bring about price regulation or any other regulations they are the sovereign governments and it is for them so to do. The Commonwealth makes the point--
—You would not support it.
—Order! I suggest that honourable senators give an opportunity to the Leader of the Government to answer a question that was asked in all seriousness.

—I repeat that it is within the sovereign powers of the States to carry out those functions that Senator Georges desires be carried out. They can do so if they judge them to be effective. They are not within the Commonwealth's powers. The Commonwealth believes that the real thrust should be to get an understanding and an agreement on wage restraint throughout Australia and, by so doing, lower inflation and interest rates. I remind the Senate once again-this was the thesis of Mr Hayden in his 1975 Budget; I have not heard it altered since-that the way back to re-employment is to bear down on inflation because inflation creates unemployment. To bear down on inflation is the path back. I commend the rereading of Mr Hayden's 1975 Budget Speech to the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. I refer to the Opposition's education policy announced on the weekend, half of which is generally commendable and, following the Government's lead, bipartisan. I refer in particular to the distinctive aspect of the policy which is the divisive and mean-spirited attack on resourceful non-government schools. Does the Government totally reject the Opposition's policy that tax paying families associated with these schools be denied altogether even the minimum proportion of public support they now receive? Is it not patently false to claim that the Government has reduced financial support for government schools? How does the current level of support for government schools compare in real terms with that for the last year of the Labor Government? Finally, does the Government totally reject the Opposition's policy of isolating the tall poppies and then ruthlessly cutting their heads off?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might have missed the second last point of the question. I invite the honourable senator--
—I raise a point of order. The question related to the policy of the Australian Labor Party; it did not relate to a matter within the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister.
—There is no point of order. I call the Minister.

—It is interesting to see how sensitive Senator Tate and other people are about this question being asked or answered. The Labor policy remains to be filled out in some details. There are a number of areas in which Labor policy agrees with existing policy and with what the Government is now doing. There are parts of the policy with which the Government would agree. For example, we would agree with the need for greater equality of opportunity for all schools and some of the special programs which are contained within that kind of commitment. We would agree with the commitment to improve resources for children in the most needy non-government schools. That is our policy now. It is a policy where the resources in non-government schools are directed most to those who are most needy.

ANSWER.PARA: We would agree with the need for increased retention rates in schools. We are working towards those. I instance the increased availability of a Secondary Allowances Scheme this year to try to help with retention. We would agree with the call for improved basic learning skills in primary schools and for greater public accountability. There is a lot about the policies which is bipartisan. There is much about education policy in Australia which is bipartisan, and it should be understood in those terms. Senator Teague asked about a couple of aspects of the policy. There are a couple of aspects with which we disagree and where we think that what Labor is proposing is divisive, discriminatory and where yesterday's problems are being resurrected to try to divide the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —By yesterday's men.

—Senator Martyr says 'by yesterday's men'. We believe every school child in Australia, whether attending a government or a non-government school, is entitled to a certain basic level of support. Our policies promise this. The policies proposed by the Labor Party do not. In fact, they say quite specifically that some Australian children will not get any basic level of support. As I understand the Labor Party policy as it was set out at its biennial conference and as I read the statements which followed it, in spite of the twisting and turning by the shadow Minister in the last week or two, my estimate is that something like 96,000 Australian children will lose any entitlement to government support if this policy is applied. The Labor Party is sensitive about this issue because after the National Times last week published what was called a hit list I noticed that the shadow Minister wrote in the following week to say that there was no hit list. It then turned out that the list had been supplied to Mr Geoff Kitney by the Labor Party.

—I raise a point of order. Under Standing Orders a Minister is not allowed to debate an issue. Mr President, I put it to you that in the Minister's last statements he started to debate the issue and should not have been allowed to continue.

—There is no point of order. It has been a practice in this place for some time for questions to be asked from both sides seeking comment on policy. I remind honourable senators that many loaded questions were asked in this place in the last few weeks because of a State election that was about to take place. The replies to those questions required a response which could have been regarded as both political and debating. I place this question, as has been the practice in the past, in the same category. There is no point of order.

—The next area in which there is disagreement is in the desire of the Government to maintain a percentage link with the cost of educating children in government schools when the amount to be given to non- government schools is determined. The Labor policy, as I understand it, is in contrast and would have the potential to give less money to many children if that percentage link were abandoned. Senator Teague also asked me a question about the level of support--
—Support for government schools.

—I thank the honourable senator. He asked a question about the level of support for government schools since we took office. The present Government gives more money in real terms, after allowing for inflation, to support the running costs in government schools. It is giving more this year, it gave more last year and it will give more next year than was given in the last year of the Labor Government. The claim that we have abandoned government schools is patently untrue. I come back to where I began and say that the many areas of agreement give a good basis for a bipartisan approach to do what is really necessary in education-that is, to improve outcomes for Australian children wherever they are. To the extent that we can work on that bipartisan arrangement we will do so. But in areas where we disagree and where we think the policy that has been proposed will diminish the opportunities for Australian children, we will oppose it and we will continue to espouse what we believe to be just and reasonable policies.

—More than at the races.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, relates to the drought fodder subsidy and the legislation we recently passed to grant that drought fodder subsidy. Is it a fact that although the legislation has been passed and many applications have already been processed, in fact the applicants have not yet received moneys to which they would be entitled under the provisions of the legislation because there are some agreements with the States which have to be signed and which the States have not yet got around to signing? Is this the reason for the delay? If not, what is the reason for the delay? When are the applicants likely to be paid their urgently needed drought relief?
—I will ask the Minister for Primary Industry for a reply.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. If the employment situation is so grim that it demands a $700m expansion of capital works, as proposed by the Deputy Prime Minister, why did the Government fail to make provision in the Budget for adequate capital works?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government made very substantial provision in the Budget for capital works. For example, the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program is of enormous significance. Soon the Senate will have legislation before it in regard to that program. The Budget provides for very substantial public works in regard to airfields, water resources programs and other constructions. The Government is endeavouring to ensure that it can get effective control of inflation-that is, deflation-and provide effective opportunities for job creation without substantially inflating deficits. That ought to warm the hearts of members of the Australian Labor Party because until recently it was Mr Hayden's thesis that we must not substantially enlarge the deficit or we will create unemployment and inflation. I repeat that the Government's aim is to bear down on wages and therefore to bear down on costs, at the same time recognising that in the government sphere-Commonwealth, State and local government-there could be a saving of $700m and in the private sector there could be a saving of at least another $2 billion and that as those savings would not be inflationary, because they would not cause an increase in the deficit, they could be used to put people to work in an effective way without causing inflation. It would be job insurance, job creation, in the best sense and would not result in disemployment by blowing out the deficit.

ANSWER.PARA: The figure of $700m is not, in itself, a figure on which we should be bearing. I pointed that out in answer to Senator Button. The Government aims to get a wages freeze right across the board, throughout commerce and industry and throughout the services or tertiary sector so that much more money can be put to work, in a deflationary sense, to save existing jobs, to restore profitability to industries that would otherwise disemploy and in fact to prepare for the future so that, as the recession rolls back, Australia will be in a competitive position in regard to other countries. That is the primary thrust of the Government's approach. It makes very good sense and it ought to be supported by all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I thank Senator Carrick for recycling yet again his 1976 speeches, but will he answer the question? Why was this policy not included in the Budget which was presented less than three months ago?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was not the question at all. The question was whether we had an adequate public works structure in the Budget. I replied that the Budget provided for a substantial amount of public works. Since the Budget was presented, because of a rapid fall-off in overseas purchases from Australia and a rapid rise in wages, there has been a more severe rate of disemployment than the Government or anyone else foreshadowed. It therefore became necessary to get to the very heart of that problem, which is recognised by all economists in the country as being the upsurge of wages, which have risen by something like 17 1/2 per cent. Unless wages can be restrained costs cannot be restrained and if costs cannot be restrained we will have disemployment running very fast. The logical thing to do is to bear down on inflation. That, in turn, will bear down on interest rates. The Budget gave to every family very substantial extra support by way of family allowances, tax concessions, housing interest rate subsidies and a variety of concessions in the sense that it aimed to get wage restraint. This is a further step in that regard. Incidentally, it is supported in very many parts of industry where employees-decent Australian workers-on their own initiative are coming forward to employers and offering, whether by way of a four day working week or the restraint of wages, to do precisely what this Government is aiming to do today.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the repeated requests by me and by the Government Members Committee on Law and Government to clarify and set out in detail the principles and practices applied by Australia in dealing with the situation and needs of Australian citizens who come into conflict with the law in foreign countries. I refer also to the reply received by letter dated 13 September from the Foreign Minister on this subject and the further reply which I received today. As the propositions set out in these letters are generalised, unclear and have in any event not been exposed publicly or debated in this Parliament, I ask the Minister: Firstly, are the letters intended to be the Government's considered statement on these issues or will the Government be making a further statement to the Parliament before it rises for Christmas on its obligations to its citizens abroad? Secondly, in either event, will the Government see that there is opportunity for the Parliament to consider and debate the adequacy of the arrangements made for the protection of the rights of its citizens abroad?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — There has been correspondence between the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Law and Government Committee and I think we referred to that in this place on an earlier occasion. There has also been correspondence with Senator Missen on the subject of Australians who come into conflict with the law in foreign lands. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, in his response to Senator Missen, said that he believed his letter to the Secretary of the Law and Government Committee adequately explained the Australian Government' s position. The Minister also said that at this stage he did not see any advantage in making any special statement to the Parliament on this question. He said that there was nothing new to add and therefore the statement could only reiterate established policy and practice in this field. The Minister said that nevertheless he would keep the issue under review. If the Senate were to debate the matter or to place further specific questions before the Foreign Minister I feel sure he would respond to them. As to whether any special statement is to be made before the Parliament rises, I can only state what I have just said on behalf of the Foreign Minister.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister seems to ignore the fact that I am talking about letters between the Foreign Minister and myself and between the Foreign Minister and a Government members committee, which have not in any way been exposed to this Parliament so that they can be debated in this Parliament. Therefore does the Foreign Minister have any objection to the tabling and incorporation in Hansard of that correspondence so that there can be a proper debate in this Parliament of the policies being pursued by the Government on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think the Foreign Minister would not be in a position to state that he did not wish letters to be tabled in the Senate. If the Law and Government Committee or its chairman or any honourable senator who has correspondence wishes to table it I do not think the Foreign Minister is in any position to decree otherwise. If correspondence is tabled and there is a debate in the Senate then I would undertake to refer that matter to him. Senator Missen asked whether there was to be a debate in the Senate. It would not be a debate that would be initiated by any statement I would be making on behalf of the Foreign Minister.

—Before calling any other honourable senator I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of former Senator Gordon Davidson. We extend to Mr Davidson a very cordial welcome back to Canberra and to the Senate today.

—I draw the attention of the Leader of the Government in the Senate to remarks made on the Australian Broadcasting Commission radio program AM today by the Western Australian Premier, Mr O'Connor, that a wages freeze could not work without a prices freeze. Since a similar plan was attempted in 1977 with some co-operation from most Premiers and with some recognition of the role of prices but was a dismal failure, I ask: What makes the Leader of the Government now think that this current half-baked proposal will get to first base when even this least dazzling of State Premiers can see through it within 12 hours?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that the Commonwealth Government's proposal has been rejected by the Premiers or by the people of Australia. I think that we should wait until the Premiers Conference gives more thought to the situation.
—O'Connor says that one is no good without the other. The question is whether you will adopt both.

—I am grateful for Senator Walsh's help. Senator Bolkus asked whether I heard the Western Australian Premier this morning; I did. As to wages and prices, the first thing I repeat is that the cost-that is, the price- of anything is the labour of its production. Therefore, of course, prices bear a direct and enormous relationship to wages. Equally, if the cost of labour is such that an industry becomes unprofitable, the industry sheds labour. If we have unprofitable industry, we get disemployment. So the way to bear down primarily on costs is to bear down on wages. I repeat that if the Western Australian Premier, or any other Premier, seeks, within his sovereign powers, to do what is within the constitutional power of the States with regard to prices or charges, he is entirely free to do so. I remind Senator Bolkus that the people of Australia have never agreed that there should be centralised price control within the Commonwealth. They say that price control should remain within the States, where it rests now. So this matter is entirely a matter for the States.

ANSWER.PARA: The real thrust of the matter is whether the people of Australia are willing, through Commonwealth, State and local government and through commerce, industry and services, to get major wage restraint now so that we can get to the very heart of inflation as quickly as possible. That is what this discussion is working on. Basically, it is capable of achievement if there is good will. But members of the Australian Labor Party are setting out now to try to destroy it. Nothing could be more un-Australian than setting out to destroy something that is aimed at stopping disemployment and at creating future employment in Australia. The knockers themselves are destructive. I only hope that they will get together and say to themselves: 'Let us have a bipartisan policy in this country'-the employment of Australian families ought to be a bipartisan matter-' and let us get together with constructive, sensible and decent support for the government of the day, which is trying to do the vital things that are recognised in other countries as necessary'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to that part of my question which said that in view of the fact that in 1977, with some co-operation from most Premiers, the same type of plan failed, what now makes the Government think that the current half-baked proposal has any more chance of success. That part of the question was not answered. I understand the Minister's reluctance in trying to answer it, but I should like a definite reply.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no reluctance at all. The conditions of disemployment in this country today are obviously more serious than they were in 1977. The world has gone into a much harsher recession this year than there was in 1977. The impact externally upon Australia is now much vaster. I would take it that there is far greater realisation by every Australian-by every Australian government and by the community outside-that if we are to resist this recession, if we are to get back into a competitive stance for the future, this is the real issue now. I just hope that members of the Labor Party will stop being knockers and get on with the job of helping Australia to recover.

—I refer the Minister for Education to a news release of the Department of Education announcing a campaign to inform parents of secondary school students in years 11 and 12 that they may be eligible for annual grants of $871 a child. Bearing in mind that on a percentage comparison with other States Tasmania has the least number of students going through to matriculation year-Tasmania averaging 26.7 per cent compared with the mainland figure of 34.8 per cent-does the Minister expect the retention rate in Tasmania to improve markedly as a result of the Secondary Allowances Scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The extension of the scheme to which Senator Walters referred is a Budget initiative in which the means test for the Secondary Allowances Scheme has been extended by 44 per cent-a very major extension of the means test. The result of that will be to allow a large number of parents to qualify who would not otherwise have qualified. It has the potential to enable a large number of students to remain at school and their families to receive some support which they could not have received earlier. It is desirable that that benefit be publicised. I seem to recall that in this place earlier-I think it may have been Senator Grimes in relation to the housing proposals-there was some criticism of the fact that not enough publicity was given when that scheme was extended. We thought it appropriate to make known this new benefit so that as many potential recipients as possible at this stage of the year, could consider whether they should apply. We have started a campaign. It began with some radio commercials. We have established a hot line in each capital city and in the country. Rather contrary to our expectations-we thought it might start slowly- large numbers of telephone calls have been received from the first day from people anxious to discover whether they, as parents, might qualify for the benefit. To the extent that the campaign is bringing information it will be very helpful.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, the scheme will apply Australia-wide. It will apply in Tasmania as it will apply anywhere else. I cannot say with any certainty that such a scheme would be the major determinant of any increased retention of students. It would certainly help in working towards increased retention-the same as any other increased benefit might help by removing financial barriers. To the extent that all the parties in the Parliament are seeking increased retention, this benefit is one that should be supported on all sides. It may be difficult to measure in Tasmania or in any other part of Australia exactly what beneficial effects will flow. I cannot guarantee to Senator Walters that we can tell her that such and such a number of students remain in secondary schools who would not otherwise have remained. If we know that those students in years 11 and 12 who are entitled to help have made contact with the Department, have received advice from officers and hopefully that all parents able to receive the benefit are in fact receiving it, then we as a government will be well satisfied.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment follows his answer to the question on South West Tasmania asked by Senator Chipp. I understood the Minister said that the Government was giving close consideration to the question of the nomination of South West Tasmania on the World Heritage List. Does this mean that the Government is closely considering withdrawing South West Tasmania from the World Heritage List before 13 December when it is likely that the nomination would be accepted and South West Tasmania would in fact be added to the World Heritage List? If not, what other meaning did the Minister's words have?

—No one would suggest that the question I answered was a Dorothy Dixer. The words I quoted were the words provided by the Minister whom I represent as words are provided in relation to numbers of contentious issues. I do not know of any proposal that may suggest that Australia is intending to withdraw the nomination. The words I gave were the words provided. They mean what they say.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer how the figure of $700m-which was announced by the Government as the saving which will be spent on other projects instead of pay rises-was calculated? Is it net of income tax drawback? If not, how much actually will be available? If this wages freeze were to be extended across the board-as Senator Carrick keeps suggesting-and the private sector followed suit, what would be the amount involved in loss of income tax from those wages?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not think I have with me the precise breakup of the figure. Whether it was stated by the Treasurer or not, it was intended that the gross amount of the wage increase savings would be expended as far as the Commonwealth was concerned. Approximately $300m is possibly the Commonwealth's share of this, but it was not intended to claw back tax before having that expenditure in the community for capital works, welfare housing or whatever. I could get a breakup of the figure of approximately $700m that was mentioned, but as far as the Commonwealth is concerned it would not claw back personal tax out of it. I would have to get those figures for the honourable senator.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. A number of areas in Western Australia are now drought declared and qualify for direct Commonwealth assistance by way of interest and fodder subsidies. The fodder subsidy is not for agistment when stock are taken to areas where feed is available but is available if the feed is taken to the stock. Agistment is not a practical option for the eastern mainland States where there are so few areas where any surplus grazing capacity exists but it would be the best option for most drought areas in Western Australia. The main advantages of agistment are that weeds are not spread in the hay and grain and most of the wheat belt is enjoying an excellent season. Also, it is now lightly stocked because of drought in recent years. Because the direct Commonwealth drought assistance seems to contain a bias against Western Australian farmers and because it encourages bad farming practices, would the Government consider widening its provision to include assistance for agistment? The term 'stubbles' is included in category 3 of the list of fodder which will attract a subsidy. Any farmer will confirm that 'stubble' is a term used to describe the remains of a harvested crop standing in a paddock.
—Is this a question or a lecture?
—Senator, I suggest that you ask your question rather than make a speech on fodder conservation.
—The point I was making is that in my opinion the term 'stubble' is misused in that advertisement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two aspects of the question. The honourable senator asked whether the Government would consider widening the provision for fodder assistance to include agistment. He correctly pointed out that the drought relief measures announced by the Government do not cover the costs of agisting sheep or cattle, instead of purchasing fodder for feeding to them on the home property. I will put that request to the Minister for Primary Industry for his consideration. I would say, in undertaking to do that, that the announced drought relief measures are extremely generous already in the sense that they respond to the very real problems which exist because of the widespread nature of the drought. It is an unusual situation in that so much of rural Australia is in drought. For that reason, of course, agistment is simply not available in many parts of Australia. Many people who wish to retain their breeding stock will need to purchase fodder, and for that reason the Government was responding to the particular and difficult circumstances of this widespread drought.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that the expression 'stubbles' appears in the advertisement. However , it is made quite clear in the application form that no assistance is provided for agistment. The expression 'stubbles' appears with a series of other words which clearly relate to fodder which has been removed from the ground. I think on a proper reading of the advertisement it would be understood that the stubble referred to is of the harvested, baled and delivered variety. I think anyone who got to the point of making an application and who read the application form would see that agistment on stubble or whatever is not covered by this scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. In view of the Government's enthusiasm for a wages freeze with the co-operation of the States and the lamentable history of such attempts in the past, for example, in 1977, why has the Government never sought constitutional power by way of a referendum to enable the Federal Government to get exclusive power over prices and incomes? Does this lack of will not underline the stunt nature of the present call for a wages freeze?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the event of a co-operative Commonwealth-State approach to the question of a wages freeze, there is no shortage of constitutional power. The fact is that the States already have that constitutional power. If it is thought , after consultation between the Commonwealth and the States, that the appropriate way to proceed in this matter is by way of some form of statutory control on wages, that could in fact be achieved. So if we were to get a co- operative approach between the States and the Commonwealth the point raised by Senator Foreman would not be a point of concern at all. The Commonwealth's reservation with respect to seeking the constitutional power referred to by the honourable senator is rooted in its conviction that the Australian Labor Party would probably use such a power to extraordinarily ill-effect and to the great detriment of this country. It has never been the view of honourable senators on this side of the chamber that that is a power which should be vested in the Commonwealth Government.

ANSWER.PARA: In this case we are approaching the matter knowing that a significant number of employees in different areas have acknowledged the need for wage restraint. Notwithstanding the very disturbing increase in the rate of earnings over the last six months, some groups within the community have shown themselves to be concerned about the economic position of their companies and their employers and have been prepared to come to co-operative arrangements. The Government hopes that that spirit is widespread in the Australian community. At a time when there are significant difficulties in this community we should be prepared to work together to achieve a solution which will spread the benefits of this very great country more equitably among the people who inhabit it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health noted an item in yesterday's Age quoting the latest report on medical manpower in Victoria which shows that the number of new doctors has been growing six times faster than the population? The report further states:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the quality of medical training and medical care may fall if there is not a substantial reduction in medical school intakes and further restrictions on foreign doctors.

Will the Minister inform the Senate whether the figures cited by the Age are correct and what would be the comparable figures for Australia? Further, what is the point of view of the Department of Health regarding the possibility of lowering of medical standards as indicated by the article?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has some reluctance to try to direct universities as to the numbers of people they should let into faculties. It is true that for some of the high technology or expensive faculties-for instance, the faculties of medicine, engineering and veterinary science-there are arrangements with the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission as to the number of students we can support. I suppose to that extent it would be possible for the Commonwealth to lower the number of supported students and perhaps in that way to limit medical manpower.

ANSWER.PARA: I can advise the honourable senator that I have seen the story in the Age newspaper of 15 November. Although I am not able to confirm that the figures quoted are correct, I have no reason to doubt them. The figures have come from reputable researchers at Monash University. I would imagine that they are correct and that they set out a situation which has developed and emerged.

The Commonwealth has, for some years, had under consideration the question of medical manpower, the levels of immigration, the levels of foreign-trained as opposed to Australian-trained doctors. The difficulty is to determine the economics of the medical market place. Does in fact a market model exist so that more doctors means keener competition, with benefits? There is some evidence of this. The same report from the researchers shows, for example, that at the same time as there has been an increase of doctors a better distribution of medical manpower has emerged. Many doctors have moved into areas which were previously underprovided. The other model of the medical market-place is a cost generated model which suggests that more doctors mean higher costs. Depending upon which of those models one believes is the correct one, one will make one or other decision on what one does about medical manpower and its control. Government has been considering this matter. It has not wanted to interfere more intensively at the Commonwealth level. But we are concerned and we will put these figures under study. I will seek from the Minister for Health any further comment he may wish to offer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Leader of the Government in the Senate agree with Mr Roberts Dunstan, a former Minister in the Victorian Liberal Government who said that the Fraser Government has failed to cure Australia's economic problems after repeated promises that it could do so? Will the Minister name those countries in the free world to which he alluded earlier that have reduced real wages? Will he indicate also the level of unemployment in those counries? Finally, when will the Government be in a position to report to the Senate with a set of proposals which will aim at reducing unemployment in key regional areas such as Newcastle, Wollongong or the Mornington Peninsula?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see the gentleman's comments so I cannot comment upon them at all. In countries such as the United States of America, the United Kingdom and some other European countries there has been a reduction in wages.
—In real wages?

—In real wages. It is true that the unemployment rates in those countries have been very high. Those countries believe that the way to get unemployment down is to get inflation down. I take it that Senator Button does not believe that so I remind him of what the Leader of the Australian Labor Party had to say. This is important. People tend to forget it. A Labor leader in government with a budgetary consideration ahead of him knows the truth. Mr Hayden said:

ANSWER.PARA: On the economic front, inflation is this nation's most menacing enemy. We aim to curb it. Unless this aim is achieved, the nation's productive capacity will run down and job opportunities will diminish.
Our present level of unemployment is too high. If we fail to control inflation unemployment will get worse.
He continued:

We are no longer operating in that simple Keynesian world in which some reduction in unemployment could, apparently, always be purchased at the cost of some more inflation. Today, it is inflation itself which is the central policy problem. More inflation simply leads to more unemployment.
He then went on to say that this problem could not be solved by increasing the deficit. Honourable senators should remember what he said. He continued:

Some might argue that a large deficit could be offset by a tough monetary policy-but this would mean greatly increased interest rates, disruption in financial markets, further depression of business confidence and serious company failures. This is an unacceptable option.

In other words, Mr Hayden, in his 1975 Budget Speech, said the very things that this Government is saying today: If we want to tackle unemployment and reduce it we must tackle inflation. We cannot tackle inflation by inflating the Budget-Mr Hayden said this and we agree-if we enlarge the deficit we enlarge unemployment. The key to inflation is costs. Rising costs are the cause of higher inflation. Higher costs are caused by higher wages. The Australian Labor Party now finds itself in an enormous dilemma. To take the negative and destructive line that it is now taking it must reject what its leader said when he was Treasurer. He was right when he was Treasurer. He is now changing the whole of his thesis. The truth of the matter is that more inflation means more unemployment. Bearing down on inflation means that we are on the way to tackling the employment problem. I only hope that members of the Labor Party will go back to Mr Hayden's Budget Speech and read it more often.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister name one country in the free world that has reduced real wages and thereby reduced unemployment levels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that the countries in the free world, faced with soaring unemployment, have taken the main policy of reducing wages as a means of stopping further disemployment and in the longer run of getting better employment. Those countries are virtually all the countries of the whole Western world.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Is the Minister aware that legal and technical strategies are being employed to frustrate the purpose and intent of the anti-dumping applications? Further, will the Government consider excluding dumping decisions from judicial review to show the Government's good faith of its intention to have effective, fast track anti-dumping in a climate of world recession?

—The honourable senator has raised a question which certainly is of concern to the Government. We do not like the prospect of legal challenges frustrating the application of the anti-dumping legislation. This matter is currently receiving attention from the Government. I will give the honourable senator a further reply when the consideration of this matter has been completed .

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health a question about the new complicated declaration form which is to be included on the back of prescription forms filled in by all pensioners and disadvantaged persons from 1 January next. I ask: Why is it necessary for this complicated form to be introduced at all? Why can we not retain the present system which basically requires a signature on the prescription form? Does the Minister have any evidence of considerable abuse of the system in the past? What proposals does the Government have to assist the half million functionally illiterate people in this country who are supposed to fill out the form in English before handing it to the chemist? Do the Minister and the Government not realise that the notification on the form of a potential fine of $1,000 or a gaol sentence of six months will cause pensioners and, in some cases, Aboriginal people some great distress and mean that underprivileged people will refuse to complete the form at all because they will be concerned with the consequences of making a mistake? In other words, will the Government reconsider the manner in which it has gone about implementing this legislation and come back with a more simplified and humane system?

—The new provisions which the Government has introduced will confer a new concessional rate of cost for pharmaceuticals. The Government is anxious that those who are entitled to the concessional prescription cost should get it. Senator Grimes's concern is that some people may not be able to handle the forms. He draws attention to people who may be illiterate or functionally illiterate or who may have no command of English. At present I believe people have to sign their names to prescriptions. Senator Grimes put that as part of his question. I imagine that the Department of Health has existing arrangements to cover that situation. I will undertake to find out what those are. Basically, the Government is concerned to ensure that those who get the new concessional prescription cost are those who are entitled to it. I have no doubt that pensioners, in fact, will value the benefit and that new groups which will be entitled to the concessional prescription cost will value it. I think that, to the extent that Senator Grimes may have drawn attention to a problem that will require further study, the matter should properly be drawn to the attention of the Minister for Health in case there is some further action that should be taken.

—I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister please explain to the Senate how on earth the introduction of this new and complicated form on the back of each prescription will, in fact, assist even the new groups to get their new benefits? Why could not the previous simple system have remained? How would the retention of the previous system have prevented people from getting their new benefits?

—It is quite clear that with the move to a three-tiered system of charging for prescriptions, with one group in the middle having a concessional price, there is scope for fraud and for misuse of the system.
—Nonsense.

—Senator Grimes says: 'Nonsense'. There clearly is a scope for fraud and for misuse. With the new system offering a concessional rate of $2 per prescription it is necessary, in order to guard properly the public purse and the public interest, that there be some appropriate method by which we can be sure that those who are getting the concessional rate are at least those who claim to be entitled to it. The new arrangements have been introduced with that aim in mind.

—Earlier today Senator Walters asked me a question which included a specific reference to retention rates in Tasmanian secondary schools . I have now been advised that the latest figures provided through the Australian Bureau of Statistics are for 1981. They show that only 26.7 per cent of Tasmanian children who begin secondary schooling continue to year 12. This is a lower figure than in any other Australian State. The figure for the Northern Territory, which has particular demographic problems and unique circumstances, is lower. The Australian average retention rate is 34.8 per cent .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kilgariff asked me a question earlier about Darwin Outpost Radio Service VJY. I have been able to obtain some information for the honourable senator to supplement what I told him earlier. Staff representations on these points go back 18 months. Phonogram operators handle the traffic during the day and telegraphists handle it during the night. Some time ago Telecom Australia introduced an arrangement whereby outpost radio stations could make telephone calls by having VJY operators connect the radio link into the telephone network. This operated until 9 o' clock each night and it proved very satisfactory. All traffic would then be handled not by the telegrapists union but by a different union, I think the Australian Telephone and Phonogram Officers Association. Telecom is still in negotiation with the unions but without resolution.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin asked me a question last week in relation to the deed of grant in trust which might be made to Aboriginal people living on Palm Island. I have been able to obtain some further material for Senator Macklin. Aboriginal people have asked on many occasions about the integrity of the reserve boundaries and in particular whether the Queensland Government proposals may vary from those understood by communities to be the traditional boundaries of their reserves. The question relates to the integrity of the reserve boundaries, which is one point in the matters covered by the Commonwealth's unequivocal guarantee. I am now advised by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that he has been in touch recently with the Queensland Minister for Aboriginal and Island Affairs and with the Deputy Premier of Queenland, who is acting as chairman of the Cabinet committee dealing with these matters. He has been able to urge these Ministers that each community council should be informed now of the precise area to be included within each deed of grant in trust so that community confusion can be overcome.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Government does not have precise details of the boundaries of the Palm Island Aboriginal Reserve and we may need to await the issue by the Queensland Government of details of land to be included in a deed of grant in trust in respect of that reserve.
