DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Gietzelt proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government's economic policies and the continuation of high interest rates.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —All Australians must be very concerned at the rapid decline in the Australian economy. All Australians must be appalled at the ad hoc, passive and indolent attitude-indeed, the confused attitude- adopted by the Fraser-Anthony Government in respect of the economic depression which is obviously well under way in Australia. Therefore, the topic of today's matter of public importance-the failure of the Government's economic policies and the continuation of high interest rates-is one which will be looked at with interest by many people in this country. It is clear that the Government has lost control of the situation. We all know that the Government has failed in its stated objective of the last six or seven years to take politics off the front page of newspapers. Of course, politics has been a front page story in every newspaper in Australia as we have witnessed the decline of our economy in recent times.

SPEECH.PARA: Economy: Interest Rates

To begin with let me remind honourable senators that the Fraser Government took office seven years ago and promised to reduce interest rates, to reduce inflation and to reduce unemployment. We know that that statement was made with a great amount of flourish. In the subsequent seven years a great deal of rhetoric has attempted to cover up that flourish and that promise. Today we have high and rising rates of interest. The official Commonwealth bond rate is now 13 1/2 per cent. We are faced with a higher and continuing increase in the rate of inflation and of course we have record unemployment-double what it was when this Government came to power. The Government has failed in its stated aims. It has not met up with the task it has set itself. The Government has had its chance and it has failed. In other words, it has muffed it; it has stuffed it.

Last Thursday the Senate recalled the events of November 1975. In that debate there was some reference to the economic position of the Liberal Party and the Country Party at the time. I would like briefly to review that position again. By looking at the statements and claims of the then Opposition and comparing them with today's realities we can get a better picture of the failure of the Government's performance and the hypocrisy of Government members. I only need remind the Senate of the rhetoric and the distortion of facts which are so characteristic of Senator Sir John Carrick. I will seek leave at a subsequent moment to incorporate the documents from the Legislative Research Service of the Parliamentary Library which show that in September 1975 the inflation rate was 0 .7 per cent. What is the inflation rate in 1982 in the same period, the end of September? It is 3.4 per cent. The annual rate in the September period in 1975 showed a 12 per cent inflation rate. What is it today? It is 12.3 per cent. This is the sort of distortion we have had in the Senate over that period by Senator Sir John Carrick and his confreres. What did the then Opposition claim in 1975? Senator Chaney, then a very junior senator but now a senior member of the Government, when speaking to the 1975 Labor Budget, stated:

I suppose that every Budget has to be looked at in the economic context, and the economic context of this Budget is very clear. It is a context of very high inflation, a rate at which this Government ought to be . . . ashamed and it is in the context of a level of unemployment of which this Government is, I am sure , ashamed. When one looks at those two factors-the factors of inflation and unemployment-one can see that this Budget is critically important to all Australians.
Then Senator Carrick, speaking in the same debate, told us:
This Budget is a self-defeating document in that it says inflation is too high and unemployment is too high but at the end of this year they will both be higher still.

Senator Chaney's and Senator Carrick's contributions could well have been describing the 1982-83 Budget. I will return to this matter later. Senator Carrick also told the chamber that interest rates were too high. Exaggerating quite a bit, he said that 'they were 11 per cent or 12 per cent'. They were, in fact, much lower. The Commonwealth bond rate was about 8 per cent in the second half of 1975. This was unacceptably high for Senator Carrick at the time.
I refer to a debate on a matter of urgency about interest rates led by then Senator Cotton in this House. This was the matter of urgency raised by Senator Cotton:
The imposition by the Government of the highest and most onerous interest rates since Federation.
He was referring to interest rates of 8.5 per cent. He said:
That has affected the whole economic and interest rate scene. . . . It has increased costs quite unnecessarily . . . and made home ownership more difficult .

How then can this Government talk about its policies working when we have an interest rate which is now almost 50 per cent higher than it was when those resolutions were moved in 1974 and 1975? All economic observers, no matter what their political shade, identify all of these elements. Those elements are high rates of interest, a high rate of inflation and a high unemployment rate. These were considered to be the definitions of Government failure in 1975. What are they today? They are exactly the same in today's economic crisis. The Syntec newsletter, not usually sympathetic to a Labor viewpoint, states:
Both short and long term interest rates are currently under upward pressure, which we expect to continue in the near term.
It adds:
The deterioration in the real economy will force the Fraser Government to go through to late 1983.

The latest economic report of the Hill Samuel organisation suggests that short term interest rates are likely to remain under upward pressure. The INDECS group , stressing that Commonwealth bonds are now marketed by tender and are therefore subject to speculative and market pressures, stated the picture fairly clearly, saying:
Recent interest rate gyrations have been fascinating . . . Commonwealth bond yields have moved from 14 per cent to 12 per cent and back to 14 per cent.
INDECS noted, however, that these shifts are largely due to speculative pressures as a result of the new bond tendering system recently introduced by the Fraser Government. It went on to say:

In the present case, flights of speculative fancy were grounded by the news of the (recent 3.5 per cent) CPI increase and fears that inflation was picking up. Inflation will continue to be an important influence on interest rates in the short term.

Finally, let us look at what the economic experts think. The Melbourne University Institute for Applied Economic and Social Research reviewed the 1982- 83 Budget in a way which echoes the comments of Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Chaney in 1975. It stated:
Credit conditions will remain tight and interest rates are unlikely to fall.
Its 1982 summary went on to say:

This is a contractionary Budget. It foreshadows a domestic surplus at a time when the economy is operating far below full employment. The fact that the overall deficit is estimated to increase and the domestic surplus to decrease . . . reflects the sharp slowing in the interest rate of growth of output this year rather than an easing in the policy stance. This is an inflationary Budget. It will add impetus to the rate of inflation directly when increases in taxes and excise duties are passed on to consumers.

That is the prospect facing this country in the December quarter. Commentators, right, left and centre, all bemoan the current economic situation. They have no time at all for the Government's response. The current situation is characterised by unemployment of 539,200 people or 8.2 per cent of the work force in seasonally adjusted terms.

Internal predictions of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations suggest that unemployment will reach 9.75 per cent to 10 per cent by February. Others say that it could go as high as 12 per cent and that in some regions of Australia it could reach 20 per cent or 25 per cent within the next few months. Inflation after the September quarter is running at over 12.3 per cent annually. Interest rates at the low end are 14 per cent and at the higher end-trading bank lending rates-they are 17 per cent to 18 per cent. Savings bank mortgage rates for home loans have moved from 9.5 per cent in March 1980 to 13.5 per cent currently. Mortgage finance from New South Wales permanent building societies is currently available at between 14 per cent and 16 per cent. This dramatic increase in interest rates is affecting not only the home building industry but also small businesses generally as well as the average citizen in our country.

The one glimmer of hope in recent months on the economic front was the slight reduction in interest rates. That has now passed as but a brief hiccup. Since then rates have been back on the increase. The level of interest rates has a real effect. The most obvious area of effect is in the housing sector. The housing industry has been in a state of paralysis for some time. The decrease in the amount of money available to housing in 1980, 1981 and 1982 is a measure of the degree to which this has affected the Australian economy. Building activity is down, jobs are being wasted and families cannot afford homes. Recent indicators of the decline are the 20.4 per cent drop in lending for housing from banks and other financial institutions between July 1981 and July this year-that is, from $7,470m to $6,506m-and the drop in building approvals. High interest rates will help to fuel inflation too. A circle of inflation pushing interest rates which in turn pushes inflation may well be soon operating.

The pressures of high overseas interest rates will work to keep up the domestic rate-it is pretty obvious that they will remain high overseas-thereby avoiding a balance of payments problem. There is no point in our ignoring the fact that we are tied to an international system. The Opposition accepts this is a problem but it is not one that can be accepted as a fait accompli as the Government has done, which says that we have to accept it and work in that world environment. The situation is tragic for hundreds of thousands of Australian people. All observers and honourable senators know that. Yet the Government's official spokesman on economic matters seems blissfully unaware of this. The Treasurer, Mr Howard, in his euphoria, perhaps at playing as Prime Minister, a few days ago opened the Liberal Party campaign for the by-election for the seat of Flinders with a confirmation of Government policy. This was the same position as the one put by the Treasurer in the House of Representatives on 14 October in reply to a debate initiated by the honourable member for Gellibrand, Mr Willis, our spokesman. The Treasurer pointed to the problems of the recession, which he finally admitted is taking place, and said:

It is only if we are prepared to tackle those problems, to see the distance, and to persevere and not stop and go with anti-inflationary policies that we will ultimately have a hope of returning to conditions of sustained economic growth. Anybody who believes that those realities can be put aside and that we can indulge ourselves in the luxury of some expansion and monetary and fiscal laxity in policy and not see the consequences has not read the economic history of the Western world over the last 10 or 15 years.

The Treasurer ignored the fact that those influences existed in the period between 1972 and 1975. The Treasurer's appeal sounds remarkably akin to the appeal of President Reagan of the United States of America of a few months back to stay the course, or Mrs Thatcher's statement in the United Kingdom, that the lady is not for turning. The Treasurer must not have read the economic and political history of the Western world of the last few months, otherwise he would not be pursuing the outmoded and inadequate policies to which he is blindly sticking. He would not be putting forward Mr Reagan's monetarism as a positive example, as he did elsewhere in his speech of 14 October and repeated in the Flinders by-election campaign. If the Treasurer had been reading the economic and political history of the Western world in recent times she would know that Mr Reagan has abandoned his stated policies in favour of more jobs creating and expansionary policies. The very question that Mr Reagan has taken up is one which the Australian Labor Party is putting forward as a positive contribution to the economic difficulties currently facing us.

Mr Howard will know that the American people recently shifted their votes away from President Reagan's hard right line in favour of the Democratic Party candidates who have been advocating-as we have been in the Labor Party-among other things, job creation and controls on interest rates and charges. Mr Howard is moving in precisely the other direction-the wrong direction; the direction that will lead to even higher inflation, unemployment and interest rates. He led the push in Cabinet against job creation and he is leading the push in favour of the Campbell recommendation for deregulation of the finance system. If we are to believe the newspapers of this country we can draw the inference that no front bench member is prepared to debate this matter in the Parliament today because he does not support the policies pursued by Mr Howard when he was able to get majority support for his viewpoint in the Cabinet. Deregulation of the finance system would place interest rates even more at the mercy of speculative and market related ups and downs than is currently the case. That is a matter to be fought and regretted. Deregulation would be a chaotic disaster for Mr and Mrs Average Australia. I stress to the Senate that the Australian people are not interested in giving this Government any longer to pursue the policies which for seven years it has failed to deliver. I am sure that the vote in the electorate of Flinders will show this.

What has been the matter with the Government over the last several months? There have been shorter sessions of Parliament in the House of Representatives; speculation about an early election; no policies in respect of the economic difficulties facing this country; and changes to the way in which the Budget is prepared. Yet this Government suggested that some consideration should be given to an early election in 1982. It wants another three years in office when it has failed dismally over the last seven years to carry out the promises it made in such a flourish of rhetoric in 1975, 1977 and 1980.It is a failed Government, an inept Government, a passive Government and an inefficient Government. Yet it wants to have the support of the Australian people for another three years to carry on its policies.

On the other hand Labor, through the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and its three State Premiers, is providing an alternative approach. It is a short term emergency alternative to cope with the mess created by the Fraser Government and a longer term approach. It is an approach based upon rational intervention and planning in the economy. It does not allow the free play of the so-called free marketeers to take hold. In regard to interest rates, Labor rejects the proposal for the deregulation of the financial system. It is committed to a process of regulation and reform. Announcing rejection of the deregulatory recommendations of the report of the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System in itself would remove one of the pressures for higher interest rates-the mere expectation that deregulation will lift them.

Of course, there is a need for an overhaul of the financial system, as the Campbell Committee noted. Labor is committed to such an overhaul but not to the leave it to the market approach placed upon the financial system within the context of an overall approach to monetary, fiscal and general economic policy. Labor intends to plan for growth and employment. An approach which allows interest rates to rise and, therefore, credit to tighten will not assist growth in any sphere, be it in housing, small business or manufacturing. All of those sectors are groaning under the policies being pursued by this Government. Rates must be adopted to allow borrowing for socially and economically productive investment. Jobs can come only from this sort of approach. It is an approach that I would commend to the Government as an alternative to its current head in the sand, stay on the course approach.

I remind the Senate that the housing industry should be seen as a self-starter in the economy. The housing industry should be seen as a sector of the economy which has the capacity not only to employ labour but also to have a multiplier effect to regenerate the very important sections of the Australian economy that are needed to create jobs, growth and development. Surely it is not essential for us to continue with the same course of action which has been followed so blindly by this Government and which has been shown, even in the consideration of the Budget documents, to be completely inadequate and unable to reach the depth of the problems facing Australia. The Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development has referred to the fact that Australia is beset with domestic problems which have to be accepted in this country. The direction of those economic policies has to be changed. It is a matter of importance that we know where the Government stands on these issues and that we ask the Government to indicate what its policies are. The Australian people are waiting for such a response, knowing full well that we are faced with the most difficult economic circumstances this country has seen in recent years. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter we are debating reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government's economic policies and the continuation of high interest rates.

That is properly described as a matter of public importance. It is undoubtedly a matter of the very greatest importance. The trouble is that members of the Opposition do not have anything very important to say on it. They keep on bringing up the same sorts of remarks believing, I think like Mr Toad of Toad Hall, that they said it once, they said it twice, they said it thrice and, therefore, it must be true. Of course, it is not true. It contains a large number of gross misconceptions. The learning curve of members of the Opposition in economic matters is a horizontal straight line. I would like to point out just some of these gross misconceptions which were revealed in Senator Gietzelt' s speech. The first relates to interest rates. Interest rates are the price of money and they respond, like any other commodity, to the laws of supply and demand. But they do have a minimum rate below which they cannot in practice fall , and that is the inflation rate. In the economically sophisticated climate in which we now live depositors no longer accept that they should have a negative interest rate. The old idea of people leaving savings with savings banks and getting less than the inflation rate-in other words, losing money-no longer exists. People are looking for reasonable interest rates. What they are looking for are real interest rates. So there is a level below which interest rates will not fall, and that level is the rate of inflation.

The second point I want to make is that we should be clear that not everyone loses by high interest rates; some people gain. Lenders gain. The beneficiaries of high interest rates are often small people-very much smaller than the people who are borrowing. Small people gain by their insurance, their superannuation and their savings being at higher rates because of high interest rates. I am not using this as an argument for having high interest rates but a fact which we should take into account is that the social effects of high interest rates are not all adverse.

The third and most important point is that government can control the money supply or interest rates. It can control one or the other, but not both. If it tries to control both, it introduces the most disastrous distortions into the whole economic system. We believe-I am absolutely sure we are right-that we must control the money supply as it is one of the very few weapons any Federal government has in trying to keep inflation under control. I have no doubt that the Australian Labor Party would let the money supply rip, as it did in the Whitlam years-in one year there was a 27 per cent increase in the money supply- with consequential disastrous effects on inflation. We are not prepared to take such an irresponsible attitude. We believe we must control the money supply as one of the key roles of a government in the economy.

Another point on the same matter is that Australia is part of the world economy . We cannot isolate ourselves from the world economy and the effects of interest rates in other countries. Of course sometimes this can help us. In recent months interest rates in Australia have fallen, primarily because of the fall in other countries. For instance, the United States prime lending rate peaked at 16.5 per cent in June. It is now 11.5 per cent to 12 per cent. Our interest rate on Treasury bonds, which peaked at 16.4 per cent in June, is now down to 14 per cent. There have been small falls in private sector interest rates. For instance , interest rates on large trading bank overdrafts have fallen by between 1 per cent and 1 1/2 per cent. But we will not get a sustained fall in interest rates until we can get the inflation rate down, because that is the floor under which interest rates will not fall.

Of course governments can influence interest rates; it is not as though we can do nothing about them. The prime way we can do that is by keeping the Government out of the money market, keeping it from competing for the available money by keeping domestic deficits low. But what governments cannot usefully do is arbitrarily try to keep interest rates below the market rate. If they do that- this has been tried by a number of countries and these consequences have always followed-the supply of money dries up and the people the government is trying to help by arbitrarily keeping interest rates down actually lose because they cannot borrow as there is no money to borrow. They then have to go elsewhere and probably have to pay exorbitant interest rates for their money. The Government cannot arbitrarily keep interest rates below the market value. As I understand the Labor Party's policy, as explained by Senator Gietzelt and others, in effect the Labor Party would go for high deficits and let the money supply blow out. The consequences would be rapidly rising inflation and rapidly rising interest rates. The Australian Financial Review commented on Mr Hayden's Budget approach and his supplementary anouncements of 26 October. What it stated is, I think, patently true. It stated:

This leaves the Labor Party with a fiscal program which promises nothing but unemployment and inflation on a larger scale than we have now, and the prospect of further involuntary devaluations of the Australian dollar as we are locked into a devaluation/inflation spiral.

That will be the consequence of following the line advocated by Labor spokesmen. The Government's policy is to get inflation down as a contribution to lower interest rates and aim for small domestic deficits to keep the pressure of government demand out of the market place for the funds available for investment .

The second prong of the matter of public importance is the wisdom or effectiveness of the Government's economic policy. Everyone here, and I think everyone in the country, recognises that we are in the middle of a world recession, by far the worst since the Great Depression of the 1930s. We are, as a country, peculiarly vulnerable to international conditions because we are one of the great overseas trading nations of the world. We export 15.8 per cent of our gross domestic product. That is about the same level as Japan, which is regarded as a country peculiarly dependent on international trade, and much higher than that of the United States, for instance. The three prongs of our international trading economy are all in trouble at the same time. Primary products are in trouble because of the drought, mineral exports are in trouble because of depressed world commodity prices and demands, and our manufacturers are in trouble because we have priced ourselves out of the competitive markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the evidence, Senator?

—I will come to the evidence in a moment. We are running-this is perhaps the key point in the evidence-a trading deficit on our current account of $9,000m a year. Imports are worth $9,000m more than exports. This is a situation that cannot long continue. What is the Government doing about it? Its policies have sheltered Australia and Australians for a long time from much of the effect of the international recession. If the recession had been of a normal length, those policies would have been effective. The trouble is that this recession has gone on for much longer than any recession since the Great Depression and the consequences for us are here now. As a great trading nation we have to face up to the problems and tackle them as a nation. What do we do? I do not think there is anything the Government can do directly about the drought. I suppose the last Prime Minister who thought he could make it rain was Mr Whitlam, but I do not think he would have made a very successful job even of that. We are providing assistance for the people in trouble. We have a generous and effective program of assistance for people in trouble. One of the difficulties-this came out in Question Time today-is that part of the program of assistance has to be administered through State governments and some of the State governments-for example, the Government of my own State of Victoria-are not being as prompt and efficient in distributing these funds as they should be. But I think the program is generous and appropriate. That is what we can do for the primary industry sector. We must all hope that the drought will be relieved as soon as possible because it is having devastating effects on our national economy and, particularly, on our rural economy.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the question of our mineral exports. The demand and commodity prices for our mineral exports are, as I said, both down. It is a crazy time to be pushing up the costs of our minerals by excessive wage demands and by a reduction in working hours, which is just another way of getting a wage rise. Worse still, our export port conditions are dreadful. The industrial turmoil in our ports is difficult to understand. If the situation in Australia were viewed from overseas-from the Philippines or somewhere like that-it would seem that we have it made, that we have everything going for us. The only dangers we have are ourselves and our lack of reliability as suppliers. Supplies may be promised to companies for delivery on a particular date but if those supplies come from Australia the companies cannot be sure there will not be a strike on the waterfront, that Wran's navy will be not be operating off the coast again and that the supplies will be delivered on the due date. We must eliminate that because it is enormously damaging to our reputation and our performance as an international commodity supplier.

With regard to manufactured exports, here, too, we have the same problems of excessive wage increases and the campaign for shorter hours, which again raises the unit costs of labour. In the year ended in June wages rose by 3 per cent to 4 per cent more than the rise in the consumer price index. Average wages rose by 16.4 per cent, as compared with a CPI increase of 12.3 per cent. At a time when our gross domestic product, the product of the whole community, is static or possibly decreasing, it is disastrous for a sector of the economy to demand and achieve more in real terms. With that situation and with a highly competitive international market, employers have no option but either to shed labour- unemployment-or to reduce investment in new plant and equipment, which leads to future inefficiency and future lessening competitiveness. Both of these are very damaging to the interests of all Australians.

At a time when our trade unions are receiving 3 per cent to 4 per cent more than the current rate of inflation in wages, wage settlements in West Germany, the United States of America and the United Kingdom, to take three examples, are all at or less than the rate of inflation. We cannot afford to go on paying ourselves a great deal more than we are earning. Worse still, because of our high rate of inflation, which is, without doubt, wage-push inflation, we are even less competitive on the international market. Inflationary rates over the last 12 months have been as follows: Australia 12.3 per cent; Britain 8 per cent ; Japan 3.1 per cent; and the United States 5.9 per cent. The average rate for the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, the developed free enterprise countries, was 7.9 per cent. We are 4 1/2 per cent above the OECD average. We are pricing ourselves out of our markets. Without doubt, this is wage-push inflation. We must get this rate of wage increase down if we are to remain competitive.

There are many pressures on inflation. I have mentioned wages, to which I shall return, but there are other pressures, some of which we just have to accept. The first pressure is the effect of devaluation. I think that everyone in this chamber is aware of the extent to which the Australian dollar has been devalued in recent months. This is essential if we are to remain reasonably competitive in international markets, but we must not conceal from ourselves the fact that it has inflationary effects inside Australia. The second pressure on inflation is the shift-it has been modest so far-towards indirect taxes. This also is necessary in the long term. We are unduly reliant on personal income tax. There must be a better balance and some shift towards indirect taxes; but again, we must not conceal from ourselves that this is in the short term, once off, inflationary. A great deal of the very sharp and very unfortunate rise in the last CPI figure was because of the effect of indirect taxes.

The third pressure on inflation is our oil pricing policy, our world parity pricing policy, coupled with the effects of devaluation. I do not want to enter into that argument again. I think that all in this chamber are aware of and accept the vital necessity of our maintaining world parity for our oil. Without that, oil exploration would die. Nevertheless, at a time when we are devaluing the dollar, it is having an inflationary effect. Those are the pressures which, I think, are unavoidable, or which we have to accept. What then can the Government do? The first thing we can do is to control the money supply and accept that because we are controlling the money supply we cannot also control interest rates. We must control the money supply as the key weapon-vitually the only weapon we have-in the control of inflation. We have maintained out money supply at a rate of about 11.3 per cent to the year ending September this year. That rate has been maintained fairly consistently over recent years. I remind honourable senators again that during the Whitlam years the rate of increase of the money supply reached 27 per cent on one occasion. That is one thing we can do; that is within our power.

The second point is that we have to press ahead with wage restraints. The Commonwealth Government's powers are very limited in this field but Commonwealth and State governments together have all the powers. What we must do, through a co-operative approach, is to press ahead with wage restraints. We cannot go on pricing ourselves out of our markets. This is the purpose of the Premiers Conference next month. Honourable senators in this chamber have shown an example in accepting restraint on parliamentary salaries. Admittedly it is within the power of the Federal Government to limit the wage increases of its own employees . There are over 400,000 people in the community employed by the Government. However, it is not reasonable to freeze their wages for a prolonged period unless the rest of the economy is following suit. We have both a power over and a duty to our own employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about prices?

—The market place provides very effective control of prices. I saw a good example of this a little while ago. In Melbourne a garage proprietor was offended at the margin he received for selling his petrol. So, arbitrarily, he said: 'I will put the price of my petrol up to 49c a litre'. He appeared on television with his petrol pump showing 49c a litre. That did not last. He did not sell any petrol at that price. Reasonable competition in the market place forced him and others down to a fair figure. We will get a much fairer figure through proper competition than we will by government regulation. If the Labor Party is sincere in what it has said time after time in this chamber concerning the importance of economic policy to the well being of all Australians it should support us on wage restraint. The Labor Party should use its influence with the trade union movement to see that exports are handled expeditiously and not disrupted by absurd strikes. If members of the Labor Party were sincere they would help us in these two areas of work for the good of all Australians. They would come with us. I do not think they will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure Sir John Gorton would not mind me quoting a statement he made way back in the late 1960s when the then new member for Issacs took his seat in the House of Representatives. Sir John said: 'This man will be a Minister very soon, so sound is he in his economic theory and so high in his intellectual capacity.' The name of the then new member for Isaacs was David Hamer who was a very distinguished captain in the Royal Australian Navy when I had the honour to be the Minister for the Navy. Captain Hamer's performance since then has done nothing, I am sure , to make Sir John change his mind concerning his high intellectual capacity or my admiration of him. I always admire the speeches and the contributions that he makes, whether it be in this place or anywhere else. Compliments in this place are normally followed by the word 'but' and I am going to add a mild 'but' to my comments. I enjoyed his speech, which in theory I could find little to fault, but the way in which he fitted that theory to the facts I believe left a bit to be desired. He said one thing that disappointed me. He said the only weapon with which to fight inflation is control of the money supply.
—The only direct weapon the Federal Government has.

—Yes. I thank Senator Hamer. That is where I vigourously disagree with him. The Government has been using only that weapon for seven years. It has been singularly unsuccessful in fighting inflation. In fact almost every other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development country has tackled both inflation and unemployment in the past six or seven years. Most of them have succeeded in beating inflation to some extent, at the expense of unemployment. The level of unemployment in most of the OECD countries has gone up but the inflation rate either has been arrested or has come down.

SPEECH.PARA: Here in Australia we have a government that has the unique record of making both the inflation rate and the level of unemployment go up simultaneously. That is not easy to do, but this Government has done it. I should have thought that therefore the proposition before the Senate today-the failure of the Government' s economic policies-to a reasonable mind, and Senator David Hamer certainly has one, would be something worth debating. The monetarist theory that the Department of the Treasury, Mr Fraser, Mr Howard and Mr John Stone obsessively pursue is not new. The one that Senator Hamer advocated today is not new. Control of the money supply is a very valuable weapon with which to control inflation if-but only if-a certain set of economic circumstances apply; that is, when the supply of goods and services is about equal to the demand for goods and services.

If we had economic equilibrium and injected money into the economy or, to use Senator Hamer's term, increased the money supply, of course we would then have too much money chasing too few goods. Demand inflation would set in and we would have an increase in prices. But surely Senator Hamer does not suggest for one moment that today, or at any time in the past seven years, the demand for goods is anywhere equal to the supply of goods. Let him show me one shopkeeper in his old electorate of Isaacs, or one factory owner in his new Victorian electorate who says: 'I have too many orders. I cannot fill the orders. I have too many customers in my shop. The demand for my goods is so great I can't meet orders. My order book is full'. With great respect to him, I say to him and to John Stone: 'Your policies have failed. Look for new ones. Look for some other method of getting us out of this economic mess'.

I was worried, as I think all reasonable people were, about the two demonstrations we had recently, one in Parliament House and one last Friday night in Melbourne. I pay no attention to the breaking of the glass door here, the larrikin behaviour of breaking through the barricades or the disgusting behaviour of disrupting the Melbourne Club. That was done by professional agitators who will cash in on the situation. I am talking about the genuine concern which brings 1,000 people from Wollongong and makes several hundreds or a thousand people march through the streets of Melbourne-50-year-old people who, since they were 14 years of age, have worked an eight hour day, who have a mortgage on their homes and who have time payment responsibilities in relation to their refrigerators, their television sets and whatever. These are real people with real problems. They are not dole bludgers any more-that phrase does not adequately cover the 50-year-old family man who has those responsibilities.

To rely on the economic theories put out by a Treasury that, with great respect , never gets out of its ivory tower of Canberra, which is still trying to run this country and advise the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Cabinet to run this country according to outdated theories in a situation in which it has never placed itself is just not good enough. I agree with Senator Hamer, again in theory; if the Government wants to reduce interest rates, one way of doing so is to keep out of the money market. One of the tragedies this year is that, through sheer economic mismanagement, the Government will have to borrow something like $3,000m on a deficit it has accidentally incurred. My colleague Senator Siddons three months ago issued what I thought was a most constructive, thoughtful, alternative Budget, which did allow for a deficit of that magnitude. He was condemned and criticised by Government speakers as being irresponsible. At least his deficit would have gone to constructive uses. It would have gone to areas which would have created employment opportunities and finally, within a short space of time, relieved the Government of having to pay a deficit. Unemployment is now at 8.2 per cent-over half a million peope are unemployed-and inflation is up again, to 12.3 per cent. And now there seems to be a knee-jerk reaction on behalf of the Government.

I want to say something about wage rises. I was a little disappointed that my friend Senator Hamer concentrated only on wage increases. He is a student of economics. He understands economics. I quote something that Senator Sir John Carrick said today. There seemed to be an irony in some of the phrases Senator Sir John Carrick used today. He said that the only true cost of an object is the labour that goes into it. The irony is that that is almost precisely what Karl Marx said.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has become a Marxist.

—No. I would never accuse my friend Senator Sir John Carrick of that. But it had shades of Marxism and there is a fallacy in that statement. Why I want to attack that fallacy is this: The Government will not solve anything if it says that the only cause of inflation is the rise in wages. I am not silly enough to say that irresponsible increases in wages do not contribute to inflation. I do say that the kind of wage increase members of the Builders Labourers Federation are now laying on in Sydney and elsewhere is despicable. While their mates are out of work, to lay that increase on a stricken building industry is little short of disgusting. It should be branded as such. Only yesterday, when I was in Sydney, I was told they stopped a concrete pour half way through, costing God knows what to the people who are constructing that building. Jack hammers will now be needed to re-start the building. That is criminal behaviour.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me look at another aspect. About 18 months ago another proposition was put forward, condemned by the Government and condemned by all the so-called economic experts in our economic newspapers. I refer to the metal trades industry award. It was said by people who did not know what they were talking about that it was a sweetheart deal, irresponsible and over-generous. Anybody who had talked with the responsible trade unionists and the responsible employers representatives in the metal trades industry would have said this: 'Yes, we have given what appears on the surface to be a generous settlement of this dispute. But we have undertakings from the main trade union and the group of trade unions not to strike for a period of years. We believe that given good will on both sides this will be a beneficial agreement, both to industry, to the trade union and to the community'. That agreement has turned out to be almost a model of how agreements should be formulated. We even have extreme left wing trade union leaders in the metal trades industry now calling off wildcat strikes called on by shop stewards on jobs and saying: 'Look, we made a deal'. This is exactly Australian Democrats policy. The only way to good industrial relations is through good will, through trust, through a consensus being made at the beginning. We believe this is the only way in which we can reach some sort of consensus on industrial relations.

Let me go back to Senator Hamer's point about the explosion in wages being the cause of inflation. Let us take a furniture manufacturer and let us try to envisage a kitchen table. The cost of that table, when the housewife buys it, is represented by the cost of the material, namely, the wood. But to that must be added the cost of the transport to get that wood from the mill to the furniture manufacturer, the cost of the labour, the wages involved in moulding that wood into the shape of a table and then the cost of the transport to the retail store , profits and whatever. Let us assume-this is a fair assessment-that labour represents 30 per cent of those costs. Let us assume also that wages increased by 25 per cent. Therefore, the unit cost of that table would be increased by 25 per cent of 30 per cent because wages represent only 30 per cent of the total cost of the table. What about the price of money? This is where I am critical of my friend Senator Hamer. The price of money is reflected in 100 per cent of the cost of that table. The manufacturer needs money to pay wages, to pay for the wood and to pay for the cartage contractor. He is working on an overdraft. According to calculations I have seen, a one per cent increase in the price of money or working capital for any manufacturer is equal to a 25 per cent increase in the cost of wages across the board. If the conservatives in this Senate wish to criticise undue and unreasonable increases in wages they can do so by all means. But I plead with them to be fair and say that increases in the price of money have as much effect, if not a greater effect, on inflation than wage increases.

Let us look at what has happened to the lenders of money-those dreadful people who are profiteering at an obscene rate while businesses are going broke and people are being thrown out of work. What happened in 1980-81? The record profits of the Bank of New South Wales rose by 33.3 per cent to $165m. The profits of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd rose by 29 per cent to $175m. Similar increases were recorded by the National Bank of Australasia Ltd, the Commercial Banking Co. of Sydney Ltd and the Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd. If the conservatives in this country are concerned about inflation, why are they not concerned about the excessive profits made by banks and the finance institutions that are the progenies of the banks?

The Australian Democrats believe that drastic action needs to be taken. We support the wage pause but we say to the Government that a wage pause by itself cannot work. There needs to be a gesture of good will by governments not to increase charges, to consult employers and to establish that employers will play the game with regard to prices. The Government should at least go to the lenders of money-the usurers, the banks and the investment companies-and ask them to join in the spirit of national detente and control interest rates to some extent . Without those sorts of agreements from other sections of the community, how can the Government expect one sector-the working man-to bear the whole brunt of the sacrifice?

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

A succession of reports from royal commissions and other inquiries on criminal activities in Australia convinced the Government that a fresh look must be had at existing arrangements and institutions for the investigation and prosecution of criminal offences of a serious kind, particularly offences in the nature of organized crime.

In the course of this fresh look, a close examination was made of existing arrangements, consultations were entered into with the States and discussions had by the Attorney-General, Senator Durack in the United States and the United Kingdom in July of this year with law enforcement authorities in those countries . As a result, the Government has concluded that existing Australian law enforcement efforts need to be supplemented by the establishment of a new standing body with the necessary expertise and powers to make an effective attack on organized crime. The purpose of this Bill is therefore to establish such a body to be called the National Crimes Commission which will be given the functions and powers necessary to deal with forms of crime with which existing law enforcement bodies now have difficulty in coping. However, it must be emphasized that the Commission is intended to supplement the efforts of regular law enforcement bodies, not supplant them. It will be directed indeed by the Bill to work in co-operation with these bodies.

Several recent royal commissions have demonstrated that they are unable to uncover and bring to public notice instances of wrong-doing not detected by ordinary law enforcement agencies. These include the Costigan Royal Commission which attributes its success in this regard to
its power as a royal commission to require by subpoena the production of documents and the attendance of persons for examination; this power is not of course possessed by the police;
access to equipment and expertise to enable sophisticated intelligence gathering and analysis;
use of personnel with high intellectual capacity and special training.

From the Government's general experience and the information obtained by Senator Durack, during his overseas consultations, the Government came to the view that the solution to the need to improve law enforcement does not lie merely in the use of royal commissions in their traditional form. The function of a royal commission is essentially to inquire into and report on the matter referred to it. It may recommend the institution of prosecutions; however, most Australian governments, Commonwealth and State, have had the experience of a royal commission recommending the prosecution of named persons but it being subsequently found that it is not possible to bring the prosecutions because of lack of evidence.

A further consideration in relation to royal commissions is that it usually takes a royal commission quite some time to establish itself and develop expertise in its particular task. That expertise and its trained staff are dispersed when the Commission's task is finished.

Having regard to these considerations, the Government concluded that, while the new form of Commission should have certain points of similarity with a royal commission, for example, the subpoena powers of such a body and the power to examine witnesses, it should differ from that body in several significant respects.

Perhaps the most important difference will be that the primary function of the Commission will not be to make reports to government but rather to inquire into areas of criminal activity with a view to prosecution action, if appropriate. It will be enabled to pass information, as obtained, to the regular police forces but, in serious or more complex cases, it is intended that it will seek the appointment of a special counsel who, if prosecutions eventuate, would be the ultimate prosecutor. This is seen by the Government as the means by which the Commission will be enabled to make the most effective input into the prosecution process. A special prosecutor appointed under the recently enacted Special Prosecutors Act could, in appropriate cases, handle prosecutions resulting from the Commission's operations.
Other important differences between the Crimes Commission and the traditional form of royal commissions are-

it will be a standing body able to accumulate experience and expertise; within its wide statutory area of inquiry it will not require a reference from government but it can be given a particular reference by government;
the Crimes Commission will be given a discretion to conduct its hearings in private; this will be appropriate if there is possibility of prejudice to the ultimate fair trial of a person;

self-incrimination will be expressly made a lawful excuse for failure to answer questions put by the Commission; the Commission can seek immunity for a witness in an appropriate case as to use of his evidence against him in subsequent proceedings; but, except where such immunity was granted, the answers given by a witness would not be made by the statute inadmissible in other proceedings; this is contrary to the rule applying in relation to royal commissions;
the Commission will not be permitted to name persons in public reports as suspected of committing criminal offences;
the Commission will not be expected to examine under subpoena the principal target of the investigation unless this person wished to give evidence.

The Commission will be empowered in its annual reports to draw attention to patterns or trends and the nature and scope of any criminal activity coming to its attention. It will also be empowered to recommend, on the basis of its investigatory experience, changes in the law or administrative action, for example, that the attention of the police should be directed to particular areas . In addition, the Commission can be empowered by a reference from the Government to conduct a general inquiry, which could include public hearings, into a particular area of concern with a view to making recommendations to government. In exercising this function, the Commission would be prohibited from naming individuals as suspected of committing criminal offences.
Protection of Individual Rights
The Commonwealth Government recognizes the need to ensure that proposed changes in law enforcement procedures and institutions do not prejudice individual rights. Therefore:

self-incrimination will be provided as a lawful excuse to answering questions by the Commission and by an amendment accepted by the Government in the other chamber, this is extended to production of documents;

when the Commission is investigating suspected criminal activities, it will be given appropriate discretion to ensure that a hearing will not be in public if the ultimate trial of a person would thereby be prejudiced;
a witness will be entitled to attendance expenses and to be represented by counsel if he so wishes;

the Commission will not be empowered to name persons in a report as suspected of committing criminal offences or as recommended for prosecution; by an amendment accepted by the Government in the other chamber the Commission is required to ensure that its reports do not, by identifying persons, prejudice their safety, reputation or fair trial;
the Commission will not be expected in ordinary circumstances to examine under subpoena the principal target of an investigation;
the legislation will expire after 5 years unless extended by Parliament after review of the Commission's activities.

By clause 7 the Commission will be given an authority to investigate on its own initiative or at the request of the Attorney-General a wide range of matters within the Commonwealth's constitutional jurisdiction. While the Attorney- General will be able to issue directions or guidelines of a general nature, he will not be able to issue a direction or guideline as to the conduct of a particular investigation. The community thus has the assurance that the Commission will be able to discharge the functions entrusted to it by Parliament , free from any extraneous direction as to particular matters.

I now deal with the very important question of participation in this national effort by the States and the Northern Territory. From the outset the Commonwealth Government has emphasized the great desirability of the States and the Northern Territory participating in this matter. A series of meetings have been had with State Ministers and the Government is hopeful that the States will recognize the desirability, and indeed the essentiality, of involvement in this national effort.

To allow for State participation, the Bill as introduced provides for involvement of the States and the Northern Territory in either of 2 ways. Firstly, provision is made in the Bill to permit a State or the Northern Territory to vest functions in the Commission by, or under, a State or Territory law. Secondly, the legislation will permit members of the Commission, with the consent of the Attorney-General, to accept functions or powers from a State or the Northern Territory, for example a commission under State legislation providing for establishment of Royal Commissions, and to perform those functions and exercise those powers in conjunction with the performance or exercise by the Commission of its functions or powers under the Bill. In this connection, the Commission members would be able to use the resources and facilities of the Commission.

Thus, under these provisions, it will be open to a State or the Territory to authorize the Commission either on a standing basis in relation to a general area or on an ad hoc basis in relation to a specific matter to carry out investigations drawing on State or Territory powers.

The Government sees the first alternative as the preferable and more effective one but the second course, if preferred by a particular State, is workable provided the relevant State legislation is in a form compatible with the Bill.

The Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence is seen by the Government as an important adjunct to the Crimes Commission and the Government is prepared to support a review of the resources available to the Bureau with a view to upgrading of its performance.

Another important feature of the Government's legislative plan of action in relation to the criminal law is the Criminal Investigation Bill. This Bill, which was introduced in this chamber in November last year, has attracted considerable comment including comments from police forces and Senator Durack, shortly before his illness, considered these comments in detail and approved a number of proposed amendments to the Bill to take into account the public response. Unfortunately, before it was possible for the Bill to be brought on for debate, Senator Durack's illness intervened preventing the matter from being brought to finality.

Mr President, all too clearly in recent months we have seen evidence of the dangers presented to the Australian community by organized crime and crimes involving sophisticated techniques and methods. While in no way belittling the efforts of the ordinary law enforcement agencies of Australia, it is clear that the problems presented by these new developments require new solutions. The Government is confident that the Crimes Commission to be established by this Bill with the new functions and powers given by the legislation and the expertise that it can be expected to develop will be a very significant supplement to the efforts of law enforcement agencies; together with those agencies it will provide an effective answer to the problems presented by these new developments in the field of crime.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Evans) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill is a complementary measure to the National Crimes Commission Bill. It is directed to ensuring that royal commissions have effective powers and procedures so that they may carry out their important functions.

In making its proposal for establishment of a National Crimes Commission, the Government of course did not have in mind doing away with royal commissions. Each type of body will have its special function and use. The primary purpose of the Crimes Commission will be to assemble the evidence for prosecutions in difficult cases of organized crimes and the like. By contrast, the basic purpose of a royal commission is to ascertain the facts as to a particular matter or matters and, where appropriate, make recommendations to government for future action. However, as the Bill now before the House recognizes, royal commissions can vary somewhat in objectives, and powers that may be appropriate for one royal commission may not be appropriate for another.

The Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union-the Costigan Commission-in its Interim Report No. 4 made recommendations for certain amendments to the Royal Commissions Act. The first was that a royal commissioner should be empowered to issue a search warrant where he believes on reasonable grounds that a person has documents relevant to the terms of reference of the Commission and there is a reasonable likelihood of the destruction of the documents. The Commission pointed out that mere service of a subpoena to produce documents will, if the person has something to conceal, result in the destruction and non-production of documents. The subpoena, the Commission said, acts as a warning to such a person of the Commission's interest . The Government broadly accepts this recommendation subject to the qualification that the warrant should be granted by an independent judicial officer. It has also concluded that the application of the provision should be limited to royal commissions whose Letters Patent indicate an intention that the provision should apply. Proposed new section 4 so provides.

The next recommendation of Mr Costigan was that the procedures and remedies available to a royal commission to deal with witnesses who failed to attend or answer questions should be strengthened. Existing powers and penalties were, it was said, inadequate. Reference was made to the equivalent provisions of the Victorian Evidence Act. The Government again broadly accepts this recommendation . The procedures provided under proposed new section 6C for dealing with such witnesses are broadly based on this recommendation.

Under this provision a witness who fails to take an oath or answer questions may be referred to the Federal Court or the Supreme Court of a State or Territory. That court may order the person to comply with the relevant requirement. Failure to comply would be punishable as contempt of court. However , these provisions will be limited to royal commissions with Letters Patent indicating that intention. In further consultations with Mr Costigan the need emerged to put beyond doubt the power of the Commission to communicate information and documents to a Special Prosecutor, the National Crimes Commission or Attorney-General of the Commonwealth, State or Northern Territory and law enforcement bodies generally. This doubt is removed by proposed new section 6P.

Since 1912, section 6DD of the Act has rendered statements or disclosures by a witness before a royal commission inadmissible in evidence against him except in any criminal proceedings for an offence against the Act. Because of the existence of this section, it was the view for many years that, on the proper construction of the Act, self-incrimination was not a lawful excuse for the failure of a witness to answer questions or produce documents. However, the decision of the High Court in Hammond v. The Commonwealth (1982) 56 ALJR 767 cast doubt on this construction although the majority formally reserved judgment on this point. The actual ground on which the majority of the Court granted an injunction restraining the royal commission in question from continuing its examination of Mr Hammond was that questions were being put to him by the Commission as to facts directly relevant to issues in criminal proceedings already commenced against him.

I must emphasise that the present Bill would not affect that ground nor the result of any future similar proceedings but, given the fact that section 6DD protects a witness against use of evidence given by him to a commission in other proceedings and the need for a royal commission to establish the facts of a particular matter, the Government has concluded that the doubt as to the construction of the Act arising from the High Court decision should be removed and that it be made clear that, in the special circumstances of a royal commission hearing, self-incrimination is not an excuse for failure to answer questions or produce documents. However, to make clear that the amendment will not affect the actual ground of the High Court's decision in the Hammond case, the Government, in the other chamber, moved an amendment, the affect of which is that self-incrimination is a valid excuse for failing to answer questions or produce documents in relation to an offence with which the witness has been charged.

I explain that different considerations apply under this Bill than apply in relation to the National Crimes Commission Bill for the reason that the primary purpose of that Commission is to obtain evidence admissible in a court for a prosecution where appropriate. Thus, under that Bill self-incrimination is an available excuse, subject however to an indemnity having been given by the Attorney-General and there is no prohibition on use in a court of the evidence obtained by the Crimes Commission.

A final feature of the present Bill is the provision made in proposed new section 7AA which is intended to remove doubt as to the capacity of a Commonwealth royal commission to accept powers and functions given to it by a State government in the form of a parallel commission.

When special circumstances arise calling for the establishment of a royal commission to inquire into a particular matter, it is in the interests of the nation that the body should be clothed with all necessary powers and given effective procedures so that it can fulfill its important task expeditiously and effectively. The present Bill is directed to this end and the new powers and procedures provided under the Bill will greatly enhance the ability of royal commissions to discharge the many and varied functions for which they are established. I commend it to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill 1982

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts I present the Committee's report on the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill, together with the Hansard record of the Committee's proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Senate referred certain aspects of the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill 1982 to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts just under five weeks ago. Despite the tight deadlines involved we have addressed, very directly, each of the terms of reference and are unanimous in our conclusions and recommendations. We received 35 submissions and other evidence including clear and for the most part comprehensive material from all the major interested groups. The Committee tested the submissions in a full range of public hearings. Details of the submissions and hearings are set out in the report.

The Committee's reference was restricted to the students assistance Bill itself and did not extend to brokers issues of student finance. This was a consequence firstly of the quite specific special terms of reference given to us by the Senate and secondly of the inevitable limitation following the fact that only a few weeks were available for this inquiry. The Committee's terms of reference required us to consider the likely effect of the proposed loan scheme on existing student assistance, the proposed agreement between the Government and certain banks, suggestions that the maximum loan be increased above $1,000 and eligibility for student loan assistance. In general, the Committee found that the proposed scheme should be effective and fair and that it amounts to a supplementary financial resource available to students. However, as noted in the report, the Committee was concerned that some areas of uncertainty had not been publicly clarified at the time the Bill was introduced in the Parliament and that this had led to some public confusion. The evidence taken by the Committee has shown that these matters are already, for the most part, resolved and will be finalised in time for the loans to be made available early in 1983.

This inquiry, I believe, has been a good use of the Senate committee system for reviewing proposed legislation. No proposals to amend the Bill have emerged from the inquiry but for all concerned this review has clarified the operation of the legislation and the loan scheme itself. For example, witnesses representing tertiary education students at the Committee's public hearings expressed fears about the criteria which will be applied by the banks when assessing students' applications for loans. Evidence given at the Committee's public hearings by the Australian Bankers Association and the administering departments was able to allay these fears. The Committee, and through it the Senate and the public, are now much better informed about the intent of the Bill and its proposed administrative arrangements. I will now summarise quite briefly the specific conclusions and recommendations reached by the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they unanimous?

—The Committee was unanimous. Term of reference (a) required us to report to the Senate by today and it is good to note that we have been able to do so. Term of reference (b) required the Committee to investigate the likely effect, if any, of the proposed loan scheme on post-graduate awards, the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme, adult secondary education assistance and the Aboriginal study grant schemes. The Committee concluded that the loan scheme will neither replace nor diminish them. Its only significant effect will be to supplement the benefits that they currently make avaliable. Term of reference (c ) required the Committee to investigate the proposed agreement between the Government and certain banks. A detailed examination of the agreement that is to be concluded is outlined in chapter 4 of the report. One matter that is still being negotiated is the level of service charges to be levied by the banks on student loan applicants, but at the worst these will be at the same level as normal loan accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: Importantly, the Committee was assured by bank and Commonwealth Government representatives that banks will be approving all eligible student applicants for loans except on only one ground; that is a prior unsatisfactory repayment record already established by the applicant. Other factors, such as future earning capacity, course of study, age, sex, academic record or socio-economic background, will not be taken into account. The initial fund of $50m for the 1983 year is fixed, but the Committee has been assured that loans will be allocated by an even distribution and in a fair manner to students in all parts of Australia. The Committee recommends that for the second and subsequent years of operation the total amount available to the scheme be renegotiated and, if required, adjusted to match the best informed assessment of the needs of students.

Term of reference (d) required the Committee to consider suggestions from secretarial, commercial and other colleges that the maximum loan be increased to $2,500. The Committee has concluded that the maximum loan should not at this time be increased above the proposed limit of $1,000 for any group of students mainly because, with the fixed $50m available next year to the scheme, the number of potential beneficiaries would be substantially reduced, and we think unfairly reduced. However, this matter should be given serious consideration during the review of the scheme before the second year of the scheme's operation .

Term of reference (e) required the Committee to look at the limitation of the scheme to grantees specified in sub-clause 3 (2) of the Student Assistance ( Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill. The Committee concluded that, for the most part, the eligibility criteria set out in the Bill are fair. Again, certain aspects should be reviewed after the scheme's first year of operation, including consideration of allowing single post-graduate students to have comparable eligibility with single Commonwealth post-graduate award holders, and consideration should be given to the case for some part time students being eligible under the scheme.

The other matters to come out of the inquiry that I should highlight concern counselling, appeal procedures and the existing campus-based loan funds. We believe prospective student loan applicants should be encouraged to seek financial counselling from campus-based or community counsellors. We also believe appeal procedures should be defined and publicised in the event of an applicant being rejected by banks or by an officer of the Department of Education. We also believe that the existing campus-based emergency loan funds should, as necessary, be supplemented or in the cases where they do not now exist, introduced in all higher education institutions.

In conclusion, I would like to reassure the Senate, just as the Committee has been reassured by the evidence presented to it, that this proposed loans scheme in its current form does have the prospect of achieving its stated objective of being an effective and equitable supplement to existing student assistance. Regular monitoring and review will be important to ensure the longer term success of the scheme and its possible further liberalisation. We recommend that all interested parties-government, banks and student representatives-be involved in this process of review. The seventeenth century English proverb that ' creditors have better memories than debtors' may still hold true, but student borrowers here need not fear; their mental processes and their study, even if not their memories, should be enhanced by the easing of immediate financial pressures on them. I commend the report to the Senate and seek leave to continue my remarks at a later date.

(1) The current hourly operating cost used in Government accounts for the costing of special purpose flights by the RAAF B707 aircraft is $4215. This rate does not provide for amortization of capital costs, aircrew or other 'overhead' charges.

(2) Commercial airlines do not provide hourly rates for the charter of aircraft and will normally only provide cost estimates against actual flights specified. In any event, as there are no Boeing 707 aircraft commercially available within Australia, any quotes would need to include the return costs of a positioning leg.

In 1980 the hourly operating cost used by the Government was $2,757. In 1981 it had risen to $3,633 and now, in 1982, it is $4,215. The operating cost has gone up $1,458 an hour in two years.
