SPEECH.PARA: We have recently introduced another new voting system for the Legislative Council of South Australia which requires that numbers from one to 11 only need to be placed next to the candidate's name since only 11 people have to be elected. I might add as an aside that this has caused some problems for the Liberal Party in that it put forward a Legislative Council team of only seven and discovered that about 10 per cent of its voters stopped at seven. The problem is that from State to State and from election to election-that is, from, say, a local government election to a State election to a Federal election-the voting system is different. It seems rather pointless to make Australian citizens of immigrants, thereby giving them the right to vote, if at the next and subsequent elections they invalidate this by voting incorrectly. I ask the Minister whether the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs will consider appropriating an amount of money, if it does not already do so, to provide newly made citizens of Australia with information about the voting systems which apply in Australia so that, having been made full citizens with full rights in this country, they can use those rights appropriately and not inadvertently abuse them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak very briefly on the Adult Migrant Education Program. There appears to be a presumption at all times that everybody understands English. This is not the case. The Adult Migrant Education Program has been filling the gap, as it were, to prevent those people who came to Australia immediately following the war from sticking in their own little areas only because that was where they could be understood and it meant that they did not have to learn English. There is now a greater awareness that if people intend to take up residence here they do need English as a second language. This question goes from that area of education to everything else. The other day at a meeting of another committee I had to raise a matter concerning the front door of Parliament House. People are required to come through an electronic device and there is a notice in English which states that a person wearing a pacemaker should not go through. But the notice is written only in English. That is being adjusted but it is typical of the attitude in Australia to people who come from other countries. The Government should be paying particular attention to the Adult Migrant Education Program. I believe the opportunity to do something constructive about it is in the Commonwealth Government's hands.

SPEECH.PARA: The other query I want to raise during the consideration of the estimates for the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs relates to the problem of people who have been refused an interview in their home country obtaining a visitor's visa to come to Australia and not being able to get an interview while they are in Australia. I refer to some correspondence I had with the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in March this year. I wrote to the Minister and gave him all the details. I referred him to the fact that a couple who would be in Australia for some six months on their visitor's visas has, because of their qualifications, been approached with offers of employment. I suggested at that time that it might be possible for them to have an interview while they were in Australia as an interview in Germany had been refused. We had no knowledge of why they had been refused. The Minister's last correspondence to me indicates that the reason was purely and simply that they did not have the skills that were required in Australia. I would dispute that, depending entirely on the amount of opportunities available.

In my correspondence to the Minister I stated that it was the couple's intention, if at all possible, to purchase a business. I cannot see that a skill would be required that they would not already have. The situation remains that while they were in Australia for six months surely it would have been competent of someone in the Department to conduct an interview and perhaps make a recommendation to the office in Germany that their application for migration should at least be considered in a favourable light. That would have meant that no additional expense would have been involved. That matter was raised in the letter of the now Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hodges) which has the reference number 82/8796-0924K. The letter is not dated so I cannot tell honourable senators when it was written, but it certainly arrived in my office prior to the departure of this couple from Australia to return to Germany.

This is not the first time I have had occasion to raise matters such as this with either the current Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs or the previous Minister. It would seem to be a relatively simple matter to adjust. If a person applies for immigration in another country-in this instance the application was made in Germany-the Minister informed me that they would have occasioned some considerable expense in having to travel to the relevant centre to be interviewed. I suggest that only they could have made that decision. If they were serious about their application they would have taken that into consideration prior to their putting in that application. Nevertheless, they have now returned to Germany. It was never envisaged that they would not do so. My correspondence with the Minister was undertaken on the basis that they would have to return as they owned property in Germany and they would be required to sell their house in order to have a fairly substantial sum of money to enable them to come to Australia and, if necessary, to purchase a business.

I think it is incumbent on us as a relatively new country to make it as easy as posible for those people who are interested in coming to Australia and setting up a business-thereby creating further employment for Australian people-to be given every opportunity to do so. This does not appear to be the case at the moment. I wonder whether the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) who is in charge of the chamber can give me some indication of what is Government policy on this matter so that I can know whether I am simply wasting my time writing letters when people are already in Australia on visitor' s visas or whether I should simply wait until they return to their country of origin and then make representations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to endorse the remarks made by Senator Macklin, Senator Robert Ray and Senator Sibraa. Normally I would have spoken on that topic but I think the remarks made by those three honourable senators canvassed that topic very well. Therefore, I intend to make a few remarks this evening about charges imposed on overseas students in Australia. Some people might query why I am commenting about charges for overseas students under this vote, but the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs collects the charges from these students. In making these remarks I refer to an article in the 8 November 1982 issue of the Christian Science Monitor headed 'Don't pull Economic chair out from under foreign students'. It deal with overseas students and United States colleges and universities. Some of the things that it says are relevant to Australia. The article claims that the United States makes a valuable contribution to other nations through the training of foreign students. It states that that contribution is probably more valuable than other forms of aid, including foreign aid, military assistance and foreign investment. The article states that the vast majority of foreign students in the United States come from poor countries. These students undertake studies in subjects such as business, science and engineering which are directly related to the development of their home countries. It is stated that the majority of foreign students studying in the United States pay their own way, although the article argues that students who have leadership potential but who do not have financial resources to study in the United States should receive aid from American universities, foundations, corporations and government agencies.

SPEECH.PARA: After dealing with these matters, the article compared United States funding of foreign students with the funding undertaken by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and said that, in comparison, the level of United States funding is minuscule. The level of the Soviet Union's commitment is said to reflect its recognition of the potential returns for the financial outlay on overseas student assistance. The article then went on to contrast this with the attitude in several Western countries which are 'shortsightedly . . . introducing discriminatory tuition charges'. Part of the article, which contains some critical comments about Australia, states:

Britain now charges foreign students, on the average, three times as much as it does British citizens. As a consequence, new enrollment by foreign students has dropped 25 per cent, and applications have fallen by 50 per cent since 1979-80. France has raised fees substantially for all foreign students except those from Francophone countries. Foreign students studying in Quebec pay more than four times as much tuition as Canadian students, and Australia has introduced discriminatory university fees as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Colston, you are getting very much into the policy area of aid to foreign students. Will you come back to the vote of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs?
—I outlined initially-
—Are you not now into the area of policy?

—I outlined that this is a matter concerning the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The figures for the Department show that $12m will be collected this year and, that being the case, it would be rather unfortunate if senators could not comment on these matters.
—You may proceed.

—I am not sure whether I mentioned it, but Australia has thus acquired an international reputation as a nation which discriminates against foreign students. I would like to mention what these charges are. The charges were introduced on 1 January 1980, and the basic charge then for a student from overseas was $1,500. For a student undertaking a medicine, dentistry or veterinary science course the charge was $2,000. A student undertaking either a master of arts degree or a doctorate of philosophy paid $2,500. These charges were increased at the beginning of 1982 to $1,700 for the basic charge, $2,200 for the medicine, dentistry and veterinary class and $2,500 for the MA or PhD student. These charges will be increased at the beginning of 1983. The figure of $2,500 that I mentioned will remain constant but the others will increase to $1, 850 and $2,350. I have given the charges that are currently being paid and the ones that will be paid at the beginning of 1983. I understand that if the Government is to review these charges it will have to look at the receipts that come from such charges. Last year the receipts were $7,254,833 and this year they are estimated to be $12,020,000.

SPEECH.PARA: In comparison with the education budget of $604,713,000 the charges we are imposing on overseas students are fairly small. They are fairly small in the Budget context but fairly major for those students who have to pay the charges. I believe it is time the Australian Government stood back and objectively viewed this situation. A more humanitarian approach towards overseas students and potential overseas students would not only assist other nations but also bond life-long friendships abroad for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some remarks about the delays in the London office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The Estimates Committee which dealt with this Department was reassured by Mr Menadue that the unacceptable delays at the London office for people wishing to migrate to Australia or people just wishing to get visitor's or working visas have been somewhat resolved. However, it would appear to me that there is still a large number of delays. I do not have to point out to honourable senators tonight that it is definitely to Australia's advantage economically if we can attract large numbers of visitors who are happy to spend money and have a holiday in Australia. Unfortunately, the staffing procedures in London leave a lot to be desired. Apparently there is an arrangement now whereby temporary staff can be employed to cope with unexpected peaks in the work load. I have been given the strong impression that the work load in London is permanently at peak levels with staff being unable to cope adequately. I know the Government is attempting to enforce stringent economic cut-backs but the lack of staff to handle migration and visa applications both overseas and in Australia has been apparent for some years. Surely the Government could grant this Department more money to be spent in increasing the number of permanent staff, particularly in the London office. We get constant complaints in our electoral offices about the sorts of delays that I have referred to tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I was amazed to learn that the Department was surprised by the numbers of people who took advantage of the new migrant selection system introduced in July . It has admitted to not having had enough staff to deal with the inquiries and the applications. In fact, 33,000 applications for sponsorship under the new program had been received as at the end of August. I certainly would not call myself an expert in the migration area, but even at my office in Dee Why, a suburban office in Sydney, there were many inquiries about the new scheme for weeks before it was introduced. Furthermore, officers from the Department in Sydney knew how popular the scheme would be because they asked my office to warn constituents that they should wait a few weeks before collecting the new forms from the Sydney office because the queues would be terrible. They were right, the queues stretched for hundreds of metres in those early weeks. I sometimes wonder what sort of research is undertaken by the Department before a scheme such as this is implemented. Obviously, in this case it was not enough.

On the subject of inadequate staffing, I make the point that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hodges, has apparently decided to crack down on the number of illegal immigrants here and those visitors who are illegally working. Whilst Mr Menadue acknowledged that increased staffing will be required , no allowance has been made for it in the Budget as far as I can see. He informed us that approaches have been made to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on the subject and that additional funding will be pursued. Nevertheless , I do not understand how the Minister can make such strong announcements without any backing either in the way of increased funding or increased staff. It is clear, in Sydney anyway, that the immigration staff are snowed under. I cannot see the likelihood of more duties being distributed without the work suffering even further.

Finally, I endorse Senator Haines's remarks concerning electoral reform and the need for the Government to spend some money on explaining certain aspects of the systems that apply in Australia at present. Electoral reform at a Federal level has been promised by three former Ministers. The New South Wales Government brought about a number of changes. We brought in the optional preferential system to vote for the members of the Legislative Council, the upper House. One has to vote only for the team put forward by one's party, plus one, for that vote to be formal. If a mistake is made in the ballot paper, it is counted up to the point of that mistake occurring. I believe that even though it would probably be better to have a list system, whereby a vote for one candidate would be a vote for the full team, at least this reform has been a good reform. For the lower House in New South Wales now one has to vote for only one person and, as was ruled last time, one has to put only a cross against the name of the candidate for whom one wishes to vote for that vote to be counted as a formal vote. That has reduced dramatically the informal vote in New South Wales elections for both Houses. But I do not believe that we shall get electoral reform from this Government because its members believe that the Senate system, the one in which we have to vote for all candidates at present, helps the conservative parties.

Returning to Senator Haines's point, the Government believes that by making people of Greek, Italian or Yugoslav origin, to name just three groups, fill out a ballot paper on which they have to fill in every single number, when some of them are illiterate in their own language as well as in English, works to the Government's advantage. One has only to look back at the scandalous events of 1974 where in New South Wales one had to vote for 73 candidates for the Senate, and over 12 per cent of the vote was informal, to realise why this Government has not done anything about it. In 1975 in New South Wales there was a complete recount of the Senate vote. It was the first complete recount ever held.

TALK.START.PARA: —The right person won it.

—Yes, the right person won it. I took a very close interest in it , because I was the person concerned. It showed the scandalous inadequacies of the present voting system because when the vote was recounted, whilst the margin by which I won rose from 854 to 2,016, the total informal vote dropped by about 12,000. There were 12,000 more informal votes found when the system was gone through for the third time. If it had been counted again, we would probably have got a different result again. We in New South Wales were determined that this situation would not happen again. We have run a very strong scrutineering campaign in every electorate division in New South Wales aimed at bringing down the informal vote. We have been able to do that at three elections in a row. The South Australian branch embarked on the same sort of campaign last time and was successful in reducing the informal vote in eight of the nine electorates in South Australia. We started a campaign on this subject in Western Australia this weekend. The Australian Labor Party is determined to do as much as possible not to have the system working against it. But we shall get proper electoral reform only by changing the Government and by changing the electoral legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the chamber for the Committee debate on the estimates for the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Some senators have taken the opportunity to make comments. Some have restated matters that were dealt with in the Estimates Committee. A number have raised points on which I am able to provide information . I can advise Senator Macklin that $300,000 has been provided in the 1982-83 Budget for the States to increase the levels of teacher permanency. We are aware of the concern in other States but New South Wales is the only State so far to make a formal approach on the permanency question. As far as teacher permanency in New South Wales in general is concerned there is some information that I could provide for Senator Macklin or I could seek to have these comments incorporated in Hansard so they will be available for other honourable senators if they are interested in the facts.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Haines asked about the provision of funding for information on the voting system. A booklet is to be produced in 1983 which will provide information, amongst other things, on voting systems-as recommended by the evaluation of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs on the Galbally programs. I am sure that booklet will be of great assistance. Senator Coleman raised a matter in regard to visas. I think I can only note many of the things that were mentioned by Senator Coleman. Perhaps we ought to note too that when visitors apply for visas they sign a declaration to the effect that they will not seek to remain in Australia, not seek permanent residence while they are in Australia and not engage in employment in Australia. It is important that these provisions be adhered to in order to retain control of our migration program. I will see that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hodges) is informed of the matters raised by Senator Coleman and the points she put forward this afternoon.

Senator Colston raised the matter of charges for overseas students. I think it ought to be stated that the charges for overseas students were introduced from 1 January 1981 and represented around only 40 per cent of the total average current educational costs at universities and colleges of advanced education. An adjustment of around 10 per cent in 1982 covered to a partial extent the increases in educational costs at that time. A further adjustment of around 7.7 per cent from 1983 will reduce the impact of inflation and recover some 33 per cent of the total average recurrent costs being met by the Commonwealth for overseas students attending universities, colleges of advanced education and certain advanced education courses at other institutions. As I understand it charges have not deterred overseas students from studying in Australia and in fact numbers have continued to increase. By requiring some contribution from overseas students Australia can assist additional students to study in Australia without substantially increasing the cost to the Australian taxpayer. I think it has been noted that in most countries there is a charge for study at tertiary level.

Senator Sibraa again raised the question of processing delays in the London office. My officers advise me that systems have been streamlined and visitor visa processing is up to date. There are still delays in migrant processing, with many more migrants applying than are eligible, but I think the streamlining and the catching up is working satisfactorily at present. Of course, there always will be surges of inquiries from people wanting to come to Australia. We will deal with them as early as we are able. The matter of operations against illegal workers was also raised by Senator Sibraa. I am advised that additional staffing has already been approved. Of course, with that approval the application for additional funds will also be dealt with in the usual process. Mr Temporary Chairman, I think those were all the matters raised. The Minister will be interested in the debate this afternoon. If there are other matters I have not referred to I suggest that he may write directly to the honourable senators who raised the matters.

TEACHER PERMANENCY IN NSW

The provision of funds for converting 30 casual positions to permanent positions in the New South Wales Adult Migrant Education Service in 1982/83 has been confirmed to the NSW authorities by the Commonwealth. REPLY BY MINISTER FOR ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES TO SENATOR GIETZELT'S CRITICISMS OF THE AUSTRALIAN ELECTORAL OFFICE MADE DURING HIS SPEECH ON THE APPROPRIATION BILL ON 11 NOVEMBER 1982

During the debate on the Appropriation Bill last Thursday, 11 November, Senator Gietzelt made a number of criticisms, allegations and innuendos concerning aspects of the operations of the Australian Electoral Office. I have received a report from the Chief Australian Electoral Officer on these matters and as a consequence I can provide a comment in respect of each.

2. In the first place, in relation to the conduct of habitation reviews in 1981 /82, Senator Gietzelt stated that he was misled in respect of the amount of review activity undertaken in that financial year. He said, and I quote, ''the reply that was given to me suggested that there was no curtailment of funds in respect of habitation reviews''. In fact, on 6 May in response to the Honourable Senator's question, Senator Baume said, and again I quote, ''because of the limits to which available funds could be spread over the various operations in which the Australian Electoral Office is engaged habitation review activities were reduced in this current financial year''.

3. I would not think that the position could have been stated more clearly and that answer, which appears in Senate Hansard of 6 May 1982 page 2006 seems, at least to me, to be totally at variance with what Senator Gietzelt suggested in his criticism of the Minister's reply.

4. I would add that far from being kept uninformed about the habitation review activities of the Australian Electoral Office, Senator Gietzelt has this year been provided with an enormous amount of statistical and background information. Furthermore, on the particular point of the reduction in habitation reviews, Senator Gietzelt had it re-affirmed on 8 September 1982 in answer to one of his many questions on this subject that in 1981/1982 there was a limit to funds and that habitation review activity was reduced. He was told specifically that and I quote ''no reviews were conducted in Queensland and Tasmania and percentage reviews only were conducted in New South Wales (67 per cent), Victoria (75 per cent), Western Australia (32 per cent) and South Australia (36 per cent).''

5. The financial figures which Senator Gietzelt quoted from the Appropriation Bill of course related to expenditures for the whole item and not specifically for habitation reviews. On this point I add that Senate Estimates Committee C was informed at the time of the additional estimates on 19 April 1982 that savings in this item would be necessary in order to meet expenditure in other areas. This is the explanation to the apparent short-fall in expenditure.

6. The second point of criticism made by Senator Gietzelt is perhaps more serious in that he has reflected on the probity of an officer of the Australian Electoral Office, a Mr Phillip Lewis who is one of the officers responsible for the conduct of industrial elections in New South Wales. Senator Gietzelt referred to the loss of ballot papers subsequent to the conduct of an election- that is subsequent to the declaration of the result of that election and not during its course.

7. It is quite true that section 170A of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act requires the person who has conducted an election to preserve and keep for one year after that election all ballot papers and other documents associated with it. It is also true that Mr Lewis was not able to produce for the Federal Court, ballot papers which were used for an APTU election in 1981. It is certainly not established however, as Senator Gietzelt claimed last week, that the ballot papers disappeared whilst the Court was considering the matter.

8. The position is that the ballot-papers from that election, together with the ballot-papers of the other 22 elections which Mr Lewis conducted in 1981 were bagged and placed in store in the Australian Electoral Office in Sydney at the completion of each of those elections. All bags were labelled with the scheduled destruction date. There was, I am informed, a destruction of scheduled material in January 1982 and again in August 1982. Prior to the August destruction, Mr Lewis has informed the Chief Australian Electoral Officer that he checked to see that no APTU bags were included in the material which was sent to be pulped. The facts therefore suggest that the mistake which clearly occurred was probably in January and on the face of it prior to the Court proceedings being commenced.

9. Nevertheless, there was a mistake and additional instructions were subsequently issued to each State Office of the Australian Electoral Office directing a tightening of procedures and drawing this particular unfortunate error to attention.

10. However to suggest from this, as Senator Gietzelt does, that Mr Lewis is unfit to carry out his duties as a Returning Officer or that the electoral administration is at fault in continuing to use Mr Lewis as a Returning Officer is, I believe, both unwarranted and unjustified.

11. On the third point-and I deal with these in the order which Senator Gietzelt does because this point also deals with habitation reviews-Senator Gietzelt has made the scarcely veiled innuendo that the Australian Electoral Office is biased in the conduct of its habitation reviews. He has asked for an assurance, in the first place, that the habitation reviews will be carried out on a thorough basis and not selectively regardless of the difficulties and that every Member of Parliament will be subject to no fear or favour with regard to the way in which habitation reviews are carried out.

12. As has been pointed out on a number of occasions, the Honourable Senator appears to have a misunderstanding about habitation reviews. The aim of these reviews is to help to keep electoral rolls up-to-date by checking current entries on the roll against the names of persons actually living at addresses. The reviews do not operate solely to remove the names of electors from electoral rolls; they are concerned just as much at helping unenrolled but eligible voters have their names placed on the roll.

13. The Australian Electoral Office aims to conduct a full habitation review each financial year supplemented of course by the work of Electoral Agents. The Honourable Senator is aware that funds have been sought to conduct a full habitation review in this current financial year. But the Honourable Senator knows that it has not always been possible to achieve this result-this is no secret. He is aware from the information given to him in respect of the last financial year that reviews can be curtailed because, inter alia, of the unavailability of sufficient funds. If circumstances necessitate, reviews must be undertaken or completed on a selective basis. Quite clearly high growth areas such as new housing developments, or areas of high mobility of population, or areas which have been the longest without review will be prime targets. Essentially, however, as the Honourable Senator has been told before, the selection decisions will lie chiefly with the Divisional Returning Officers because of their knowledge of their Divisions. There is no question of fear or favour in any of the operations of the Australian Electoral Office. I think it is unfortunate that the Honourable Senator should even suggest that that could be posible.
14. As was said last week, the State Member for Bathurst will be advised of the habitation review work to be undertaken in his area.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: New Pharmaceutical Prescription Form: Declaration-Immigration of Skilled Workers : Unemployment

PROCTEXT.PARA: New Pharmaceutical Prescription Form: Declaration-Immigration of Skilled Workers : Unemployment

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 6.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter which was brought to my attention by a local pharmacist, Mr Kevin Keep, who is a practising chemist with a pharmacy in Devonport. He brought to my attention the question of the introduction of a new concessional pharmaceutical benefits scheme on 1 January with the concurrent requirement that pensioners and others who are entitled to a concession fill out a declaration on the back of the prescription form. I want to make two or three points in relation to this declaration: Firstly, in relation to the beneficiaries of the pharmaceutical benefit-pensioners and those holding health care cards-secondly, in relation to the chemists and, finally, in relation to the Parliament because I think in all respects this declaration form and the manner in which the Government has gone about its imposition on the community are to be deplored.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a copy of the declaration form which is to be superimposed on the backs of ordinary prescription forms. It is quite evident that the information and the manner in which it is set out-it is computer readable-are such as would prove quite daunting to an elderly pensioner, perhaps of failing eyesight who, up until now, has been able to get a prescription without the bureaucratic hassles that will be involved in filling out this form. Previously, merely to give his card number was considered sufficient. In fact, on the front of every prescription form there is a space for the filling in of the pension number by the doctor in consultation with the patient at the time of prescribing the medicine. But the superimposed form of declaration on the back of the doctor's prescription pads is, as I say, in a form which is quite daunting to the average pensioner or health care card holder. One can well surmise, as my colleague Senator Grimes, the shadow Minister for Social Security has pointed out, many migrants and Aboriginals might be intimidated by the prospect of filling out this highly bureaucratic form in standard English which is naturally required, or in understanding it. For example, a community pharmacist in Moree, 30 per cent of whose customers are Aboriginals, has stated that there is no way that they will sign such a form because, in his view, the Aboriginals will see these forms as an expression of authority and intimidation which, from their cultural point of view, will make it difficult for them to comply. Even more so, how will the 400,000 people who are estimated by the Galbally report to have little or no fluency in English, be expected to fill in the form. The adult literacy report stated that half a million Australians are functionally illiterate. These are the people who will be confronted with the requirement to fill in this form which, at the bottom-if they can read it or have it explained to them-states:
Penalty for false or misleading Declaration: $1,000 and/or imprisonment for 6 months.

We, who have a sophisticated understanding of the enabling Bill, know that that penalty of $1,000 and/or imprisonment for 6 months is applicable only if a person knowingly or willingly makes a false or misleading declaration. But that is not what is said at the bottom of the form. I believe that, for the ordinary average person, dependent on pharmaceutical benefits or able to have accesss to them under the provisions of the legislation, to see on the bottom of the form ' Penalty for false or misleading declaration $1,000 and/or imprisonment for six months', would frighten them and raise in their minds the possibility that a mere slip, a mistake, which would make the declaration objectively false, could expose them to the dangers of those penalties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you really believe that?

—I do, I really do believe that. I believed it possible until I went and checked the legislation. Whereas the Bill states-I do not have the actual terms in front of me-that it has to be wilfully or knowingly filled in in a false or misleading way in order to incur a penalty, that is not what it said on the form. I believe that people could be mistaken in that regard. In any case , if the question is raised in my mind I am sure that it would be raised in the mind of the ordinary beneficiary.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to chemists, it is quite clear that chemists will bear the administrative burden of filling in this form. The pensioner, the functionally illiterate person or the migrant Australian seeking these benefits will ask the chemist to help him or her fill in this form. That will add a tremendous administrative burden to the paper work already undertaken by chemists in relation to the clerical processing of national health prescriptions and it will also, of course, disrupt the flow of work and the dispensing of medicines by pharmaceutical chemists. This is something which the Government does not seem to have taken into account in imposing this burden and in exposing itself to the payment of further moneys to the chemists by way of recompense for the time spent in helping beneficiaries to fill in this form. Some expenditure will be required by the Government in order to meet the claims that undoubtedly will come from the Pharmacy Guild of Australia seeking appropriate recognition of the cost involved to chemists in helping pensioners to fill out this form. In fact, the Pharmacy Guild of Australia has already made submissions to the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton). In its national newsletter of 8 November 1982 it states:

Despite the Guild's extensive personal and written representations to retain the existing system, legislation providing for the introduction of the concessional benefit and for the declaration form was passed by Parliament on October 28, 1982.

My only regret is that the Pharmacy Guild of Australia did not confer with the shadow Minister for Health, Dr Neal Blewett, and certainly, as far as I understand it, not with the ordinary Opposition back benchers with a view to alerting us to the difficulties it foresaw in the production of a declaration form in the way in which it has emerged. It is in relation to the emergence of that form and the responsibility of Parliament in regard to it that I think the most cogent criticism of the Government's handling of this matter can be made. Clause 26 of the Bill-new section 84AA (7)-states:
The Minister may, by instrument in writing, set out a form to be the prescribed form for the purposes of this section.
New sub-section (8) states:
A copy of an instrument made under sub-section (7) shall be published in the Gazette.

The fact is that to my knowledge that declaration form has never been gazetted as required by the Parliament-it may have happened in the last four or five days -yet it has been circulated by the Department of Health, as I have said, and is now in place on the back of the prescription pads of many doctors through Australia. Indeed, my information is that the declaration form placed on the back of doctors' prescription pads was circulated to the doctors before the Parliament passed the enabling legislation. Certainly, as I said, it was circulated without the form being gazetted as required by this Parliament. There has been a most arrogant assumption by the bureaucracy, either condoned by the Minister or unbeknown to him, and therefore a question mark is raised over his competent management of the bureaucracy. It is quite clear that the Department of Health went ahead and circulated this declaration form without giving to members of Parliament and the community an opportunity to see it in the Gazette and, as I understand it, even before the enabling legislation was passed. It makes the television program Yes Minister pale into insignificance when one sees the manipulation and the pre-empting of the Minister, the Government and the Parliament in this way by the bureaucracy.

I hope that somewhere along the line, either this evening or in the course of the next day, some explanation is given of that remarkable situation. The conclusion is that a form has emerged which, as I said, quite improperly and without complying with the procedures laid down by this Parliament, has been circulated and which on inspection proves to be intimidating to beneficiaries and cumbersome in the methods that it imposes on chemists to aid, as undoubtedly they will be required to aid, those who are meant to fill them out. The Government ought to withdraw this particular form of the declaration and ought to engage in the fullest consultation not only with the Pharmacy Guild, the professionals concerned, but also with the representatives of those organisations which have as their members those persons who most commonly make use of the pharmaceutical benefits system; that is, the pensioners and others who generally use the health care card system. Then there should be a gazettal of a new form, if a form is still required, in good time to allow the community and parliamentarians to review it and scrutinise it. Altogether, this is a fairly sorry story of bureaucratic indifference to those who might be affected by the requirement that this form be filled in subject to quite severe penalties . I hope that the Minister and the Government will take remedial action at the earliest opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say at the outset that I do not need a ministerial response to the remarks I am going to make. I want to take this opportunity of making some remarks about the comments the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hodges) made last week. Last Thursday unemployment figures for October were released. These figures show that Australia's unemployment is now at a record level. Unfortunately new record levels seem to have been set every month recently. But now we have well over half a million unemployed with many more people opting out of the work force. There is a real fear abroad. Those who speak to people who are in semi-skilled occupations or unskilled occupations are aware of this real fear that people's jobs are, or could be, at risk. This is a fear amongst the employed.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned that these figures came out last Thursday. The following morning the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs announced that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs will issue 31,000 visas in 1982-83 to fill gaps in the job market. Those who are unemployed or those who are fearful for their jobs might ask: What jobs are these people going to fill? The Courier-Mail on 13 November had a heading on page 1 which read 'Migrants get 31,000 jobs'. The article stated:
The Immigration Department will issue an estimated 31,000 visas in 1982-83 to fill gaps in the job market, the Immigration and Ethnic Affairs Minister, Mr Hodges, said.
Mr Hodges was reported to have said the following:
'Even in times of high unemployment, there are shortages in certain key occupations and regions . . .'
He also stated:
In the labor shortage category, we estimate that 31,000 visas will be issued in 1982-83 . . .

Many people were alarmed at seeing this article in the newspaper when we have so many people in Australia unemployed. Initially the report suggested that we were going to have 31,000 visas issued for people to come into Australia to take jobs that apparently could not be filled by Australians at that time. Surely we could obtain workers for certain key regions from unemployed Australians. One of the comments of Mr Hodges was that there will be shortages in certain key occupations and regions. If we look at the regions we would expect that Australians would be able to fill the vacant positions. It may mean that we have to help relocate certain Australians. If this is the case that help should be given. Where there are shortages in certain key occupations surely we could offer training. As far as I am aware, it costs thousands of dollars to settle a migrant in Australia. I do not know how many thousands of dollars but certainly thousands are required by the community to settle a migrant in Australia. Why cannot these amounts be payable to Australian workers to relocate them where there is a shortage in a certain region or to enable them to attain new skills were these skills are in short supply?
Following criticism by a Queensland Government Minister, Mr Hodges today has apparently retracted a little. This morning's Courier-Mail states:

The Federal Immigration Minister, Mr Hodges, defended the intake of skilled migrants and said it was a pity the Queensland Government did not help ensure more people became involved in the training programs provided by the Federal Government.

Apparently, Mr Hodges is blaming the Queensland Government for lack of application in the area of training. If there is a lack of application by the Queensland Government-the Federal Minister was replying to a Queensland Minister -it would seem to me that there should be some effort by the Federal Government to ensure that training schemes are availed of. The Courier-Mail also stated:
'Of the 31,000 visas which are granted under the skilled worker category, only 10,000 are for workers and the rest for their spouses and children', Mr Hodges said.
If this is the case the headline in the Courier-Mail on Saturday was misleading. It said 'Migrants get 31,000 jobs'. If it was misleading--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was misleading.
—If it was misleading it is understandable why it was misleading . Mr Hodges was reported to have said:

SPEECH.PARA: 'In the labour shortage category, we estimate that 31,000 visas will be issued in 1982-83'.

It is understandable that a newspaper would accept that this meant that 31,000 people would come to Australia as workers under these visas. I am not blaming either Mr Hodges or the newspaper but I can understand how this misleading comment would have arisen. Even if there are only 10,000 workers, rather than the 31,000 which it appeared there would be from the headline in Saturday's Courier-Mail, my comments still hold about relocation and providing skills for Australians who are unemployed and looking for work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond briefly to Senator Colston first, and then to Senator Tate. Senator Colston is correct that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hodges, has issued a Press release making clear that the number of skilled workers involved in the program is 10,000 and the 31,000 visas cover families as well. The only point that I would like to make and have on the record is another point made by Mr Hodges today that the State Ministers involved with migrant matters supported fully the proposed 1982-83 migrant intake. They had done this at a meeting of Federal and State Ministers on 10 September this year. That would have included the Ministers from each State-New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland-and, of course, from Labor and non-Labor States. There was agreement about those figures. Let us be quite clear. They are agreed figures which have the support of the Ministers involved. I now turn to the matters raised-
—Obviously not the support of Sir William Knox.

—Sir William Knox did support the figures at the meeting of 10 September this year with his Labor counterparts from New South Wales and Victoria. Senator Tate raised a number of matters. The Parliament has been debating questions of fraud and overservicing and medical matters in the last few months. There has been considerable criticism of Commonwealth departments because of the procedures which have been used in certain areas. At the moment a procedure is being proposed whereby the payment of large amounts of money by way of certain concessions can be verified so that we can try to ensure that fraud is prevented in another area. The procedure is necessary to prevent fraud occurring. It is not inappropriate that the people who receive the benefit should be required to make some declaration that they have an entitlement to it. While I appreciate the intervention of honourable senators who want to argue that maybe the form of the declaration needs to be improved or that other problems exist, it would help if they would acknowledge at the same time that it is necessary to ensure that those who are receiving the benefit are those who are entitled to it. It is not inappropriate to take steps to prevent fraud occurring. I will not go through all the matters except to say that had Senator Tate approached the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) he would know that the Minister is still examining a nember of matters which were raised in his speech and which went to the form of the document including whether it needs to be approved later on.

SPEECH.PARA: I think honourable senators are entitled to an explanation about the early release of some prescription pads. I am advised that the printing of the new pads commenced on 20 October. It was expected at that time that the legislation would be passed by the Parliament on 26 October. The contract printer, acting on this advice, sent one batch of supplies for 125 doctors to the road freight contractor on 26 October. He sent the next supplies on 29 October; that is, 125 doctors out of a total of 16,000 doctors in Australia will be receiving the supplies. In the event, the legislation finally passed the Houses on 28 October. The supply process from the printer to the doctor normally averages one week. On my advice it is highly improbable that any doctor received new pads on or before 28 October. The patient declarations on the new pads are headed 'This declaration form does not come into operation until 1 January 1983'. I am advised that there is a need to have a high percentage of National Health Scheme prescription pads with the patient declaration actually available to doctors as at 1 January in order to minimise any inconvenience to patients or pharmacists. It is not a very long period in which to get the forms out. It was thought that an early date for printing and distribution of the new forms was the least wasteful and most economic means of achieving this aim. That is the extent of the advice I hold on that matter. It is obvious how the release occurred. Since the forms do not come into effect until 1 January I think Senator Tate would acknowledge that the other problem he raised is probably of no account because I imagine the procedures will be regularised and proper before that date.

I come back to what I said before. We think it is appropriate to have a system that is tight enough to prevent frauds occurring. We hope it will be a system which is not difficult for people to administer. I have looked at the forms. I believe they would be ones that most people could fill in. I am advised that social security forms are written in English and not in many other languages. If any explanation of the forms needs to be done that can be arranged through interpreter services in appropriate languages.

Whilst I can appreciate that honourable senators would be concerned about any errors or deficiencies in the declaration as they see it, it is wrong to attribute improper motives to the Minister or to the Department at a time when questions of preventing fraud in other areas of medical benefits are occupying the time of the Parliament. The system we have had so far has been very loose. The amount of money involved in concessional prescriptions is $300m a year. I think the public is entitled to know that those who should receive the benefits are receiving them and that those who are not receiving them are not, by way of fraud, able to make false declarations to get them. The forms which have been designed aim to achieve that.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 24 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is David Roy Hughes of Foley Street, East Sydney, being investigated by the Australian Federal Police in regard to contravention of the provisions of the Bankruptcy Act; if so (a) why has he been able to leave the country in possession of an Australian passport and (b) for how long is the passport valid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It would not be appropriate to provide information as to whether or not a particular person is being investigated by the Australian Federal Police. Under section 272 of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 it is permissible for a bankrupt to leave Australia if he has the prior consent in writing of the trustee of his estate. Section 272 leaves it to the discretion of the trustee to decide whether he should give such consent. If consent is given it is open to the trustee to give the bankrupt possession of his passport.

Mr Hughes had obtained the consent of the trustee of his estate before he left Australia on 15 September 1981 to visit Thailand, on 11 March 1982 to visit New Zealand and on 11 May 1982 to visit Fiji. He returned to Australia from that visit to Fiji on 28 October 1982. Mr Hughes' passport, which had been delivered by him to the Official Receiver in accordance with sub-section 77 (a) of the Bankruptcy Act shortly after he was made bankrupt, was released to him for the purposes of the abovementioned overseas visits. The passport is valid until 24 July 1984.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many applicants for sickness benefit are refused sickness benefit as a result of Section 113 of the Social Security Act regarding loss of income.
(2) How many sickness beneficiaries are paid at a reduced rate as a result of Section 113.
(3) How many of these are unemployment beneficiaries who have transferred to sickness benefits.
(4) What proportion of those refused sickness benefit as a result of Section 113 are paid special benefit.
(5) What would be the estimated cost of removing Section 113 from the Social Security Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Statistics for the period July to September 1982 indicate that an average of 57 claims for sickness benefit are refused per week due to the claimant's failure to establish loss of income.

(2) and (3) Statistics are not routinely maintained on the number of sickness beneficiaries paid at a reduced rate due to the application of Section 113 of the Social Security Act. However, following an examination of computer records, it is estimated that some 13,000 sickness beneficiaries were being paid during September 1982 at the rate applying to single unemployment beneficiaries aged 18 years or over with no dependants. A further 1000 sickness beneficiaries were being paid at other rates which may have been reduced rates due to the application of Section 113.

(4) Some 60 special beneficiaries were identified as having previously had sickness benefits claims refused under Section 113. However, since some States have only recently commenced recording historical information on computer payment system, this figure may be an understatement.

(5) If Section 113 was removed from the Social Security Act, the estimated cost in respect of existing beneficiaries would be to the order of $10 million in a full year; it is not possible to estimate the additional cost which would necessarily follow in that eligibility for sickness benefit would automatically be extended to those full-time students and housewives, who are not normally members of the workforce.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the difficulty in keeping figures which will indicate in the future how often during a year the Director-General of Social Security overrules a recommendation of the Department of Health in an invalid pension application, having taken into account other factors relevant to that person's case (See Answer to Question on Notice No. 2327).
(2) Will the Minister request his Department to collect such statistics in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Before a claim for pension or benefit is granted or rejected it has to go through several stages of the administrative process and it is not economically possible to keep a statistical record of every stage. In the pension and benefit systems alone the annual number of new grants reached some 1 1/4 million in the financial year 1981-82. The number of terminations is likewise estimated to be over 1 million. The collection of such data would also interfere with the primary aim of speedy payment of pensions and benefits to all eligible persons.

It is therefore clear that the collection of statistical data must be selective . Statistics are kept of those transactions events or characteristics of pensioners and beneficiaries for which there is general demand.
(2) In respect of invalid pensions the following statistical information is available:
Four-weekly event statistics:
Claims lodged by type of claim by sex
Grants by sex
Transfers from other pension type by sex
Terminations by reason for termination by sex
Interstate transfers
Claims rejected by rejection reason
Grants of portable pension by intended country of residence
Grants of portable pension by main reason for departure
Grants of portable pension by expected length of stay overseas
Grants of funeral benefit by pension type of deceased and beneficiary
Grants of special temporary allowance by pension type of surviving and deceased spouse
Issues of PHB cards by pension rate
Issues of PHB cards by number of dependent children.
Annual event statistics:
Grants by age at date of commencement by marital status by sex
Transfers to age pension by age by sex
Transfers to sheltered employment allowances by age by sex

In addition to even statistics, computer surveys of demographic characteristics of pensioners current are conducted every three months. The information tabulated includes age, sex, rate category, marital status, number of children, income as assessed, total income, type of income, home ownership receipt of supplementary assistance and guardians allowance, country of birth, regional office code and postcode.

As I stated in my earlier answer the information you have requested does not form part of these regular collections and it is not intended to expand the statistical system to include it in the short term. My Department is, however, undertaking a major revision of clerical and ADP processes. The need for such additional information will be considered in that context.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 22 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Are self-employed tin miners having great trouble obtaining social service benefits, even though they have no income.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Because of reduced demand for tin, a quota system currently operates on tin producers in Queensland. Some smaller operators adversely affected by the quota system have claimed unemployment benefit.

Since a condition of the lease held by certain of these miners is that the lessee must work his lease in order to retain it, it is difficult for such persons to meet the qualifications for unemployment benefit, namely:
(i) the person must be unemployed;
(ii) throughout the period he must be capable of undertaking and willing to undertake suitable paid work; and
(iii) he must have taken, during the relevant period, reasonable steps to obtain such work.

The miners have now found that they are able to gain exemption from this provision of their lease. Where this exemption is granted, self-employed tin miners may qualify for unemployment benefit subject to the usual conditions.

(2) How many community welfare organisations have applied for special emergency funding within the last two years.
(3) What specific criteria are required before emergency funding is granted.
(4) How many community welfare organisations have been granted emergency funding.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Special emergency funding to community welfare agencies is available through the Grants to Community Welfare Agencies (Special Assistance) Scheme. Reference is made to the Special Assistance Scheme in the Annual Report of the Department of Social Security and in departmental access manuals, which are available to community welfare agencies.

Criteria for funding have been developed during the administration of the scheme since 1974.

Locally-based community welfare agencies experiencing serious financial difficulties as a result of the economic situation are eligible for assistance. Grants are not usually considered where alternative assistance is provided or available from other government sources. Grants are made on a 'once only' basis.
(4) Under the Special Assistance Scheme 50 agencies have received grants totalling $536,812 since 1974.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 12 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which categories of pensioners and beneficiaries have their pensions and benefits continued while appeals to a Social Security Appeals Tribunal are taking place.
(2) What time limits are placed on the continuity of payment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Payment of age, invalid and widow's pension, supporting parent's benefit, sheltered employment allowance and handicapped child's allowance may be continued pending the hearing and determination of an appeal to a Social Security Appeals Tribunal where the pension, benefit or allowance is to be cancelled or reduced as a result of a decision which involves the exercise of a discretion or the formulation of an opinion.

(2) In order to receive continuity of payment in accordance with this practice, an appeal must be lodged within 14 days of the date of the advice to the pensioner/ beneficiary/allowee of the decision in question. There is an exception in the case of invalid pension where payment will continue if the appeal is lodged within the 3 month period during which payment is usually continued following a decision to cancel.

Payment only continues for the time involved in the determination of the appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. Payment during any subsequent appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or action under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act is a matter for the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or the Federal Court of Australia respectively.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 21 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Minister for Science and Technology endorse a recommendation that a request for funding of $24,375 for box jellyfish research by Dr R. F. Hartwick, of James Cook University, be downgraded to only $9,800 and that the reduced grant would be the last Commonwealth grant for the project; if so, does this action indicate that the Government has abandoned its involvement in scientific research into controlling the deadly box jellyfish, Chironex fleckeri.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Recommendations on support for research projects under Commonwealth grants schemes are made by independent expert committees established for that purpose. In the case of the proposal referred to by Senator Jones, the Queen Elizabeth II Fellowships and Australian Research Grants Committee (QEFARGC), following an assessment of the merits of Dr Hartwick's project and having regard to the Guidelines for the Australian Research Grants Scheme (ARGS), namely, that applications for support compete on the basis of the excellence of the proposal, recommended that Dr Hartwick receive $9,800 as a renewed grant. The Minister for Science and Technology endorsed this recommendation together with all other recommendations of the Committee.

Under Australian Research Grants Scheme (ARGS) rules and procedures, ongoing projects are not supported by renewed grants for more than six years. Dr Hartwick's 1983 grant is the final renewed grant he can receive for that project from the ARGS. He is of course eligible to submit a new project proposal seeking either ARGS support or a Marine Science and Technology Grant if he so wishes.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1982 (Hansard, page 775) Senator Walsh asked the Attorney-General the following question without notice:

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1292) Senator Townley asked me a question without notice as to whether it was unlawful in the United States of America for electric utilities to impose on present electricity subscribers the cost of power stations being built, but not yet producing income.

ANSWER.PARA: I undertook to check on the current situation, and I provide the following answer:

No uniform law exists in the United States covering the setting of electricity tariffs. Tariffs are determined by separate State public utility commissions operating under State legislation. Rates for wholesale power and interstate power, however, are determined by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, but these only cover 13 per cent of total electricity sales in the United States.

As a consequence, the inclusion in electricity tariffs of a component to fund new capital works, such as power stations, varies from State to State. For example, in Ohio, legislation expressly forbids any charges for new capital works to be added to electricity tariffs, while in Arizona a component of 20 per cent is permitted. I understand that this whole issue is the subject of an ongoing dialogue between the electric utilities, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and Congress.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1436) Senator Kilgariff asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, a question without notice concerning the future of Landsat.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

The Government is well aware of the benefits of remote sensing technology, and in 1980 established the Australian Landsat Station to receive and process Landsat data for private, State Government, Commonwealth and research users.

I am aware of moves in the United States to move Landsat operations gradually into the private sector. The first part of this phased move is expected to take place when responsibility for the management of some of the present operational Landsat data passes from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration next year.

Australia has access to Landsat data through a Memorandum of Understanding with the United States Government. Moves by that Government towards commercial operation of Landsat, and further cost recovery, will, no doubt, be reflected in future Memoranda. Australia's interests in this area will be carefully examined and protected, as far as possible, with each renewal.

The Landsat series of satellites is scheduled to cease operation between 1988 and 1990. I should emphasise that other remote sensing satellites are planned by a variety of countries and agencies, and that we have already begun to examine the possibilities for use of alternative and complementary remote sensing satellites.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Security of Bass Strait Oil Rigs

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 October 1982, (Hansard, page 1688) Senator Robert Ray asked me, without notice, whether I was aware that security arrangements for the protection of the Bass Strait petroleum fields were being impaired by the inability of naval patrol vessels to operate in the region in heavy weather conditions and what action is proposed to be taken to rectify this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: The following information amplifies my earlier answer:

Naval patrol boats are assigned to patrol the waters around the platforms and pipelines and to anticipate and respond to any infringements of restricted areas by surface vessels. In 1981-82, approximately 40 per cent of on-station time was lost as a result of adverse weather conditions. Some improvement in the on-task time is expected following the replacement of the Attack with the fremantle class of vessel. It should also be noted that the producers' helicopters and work boats, which are very much larger than the patrol boats, can provide an all-weather response capacity.

The patrols by naval vessels are one element of a comprehensive package of measures that has been introduced, following consultations between relevant Commonwealth and State authorities and the operators, for the protection of the offshore petroleum producing facilities. Those consultations are part of wider and continuing consultation on security matters and contingency arrangements that take place between the Commonwealth and the States through the Standing Advisory Committee on Protection Against Violence, for which my colleague the Minister for Administrative Services has co-ordinating responsibilitity. Other measures adopted for Bass Strait include restrictions on sea and air access to the area in the vicinity of the facilities, surveillance by radar and radio and patrols by Defence Force aircraft. Also, as noted above, the all-weather work boats and helicopters operated by the producers provide additional protection.

Under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act and in accordance with the 1958 Convention of the Continental Shelf, saftey zones have been declared around each platform, prohibiting entry by any unauthorised vessel. Amendments to the Act, now before Parliament, give effect to an Area to be Avoided to which entry is prohibited to unauthorised Australian vessels over 200 tonnes gross tonnage. The Area to be Avoided replaces the existing advisory restricted area established in 1976. Complementary Victorian legislation will be required to implement the Area to be Avoided within the three-mile territorial sea.

For foreign vessels, the restrictions have been promulgated as an Area to be Avoided in accordance with arrangements approved by the International Maritime Organisation. They will become mandatory for foreign vessels as their governments pass appropriate legislation.

All-weather surveillance of the Area to be Avoided and nearby waters in maintained using radar mounted on one of the outer platforms. The unit can detect ships up to 32 kilometres distant and is operational 24 hours each day. Fixed radar on offshore installations is the most practical and efficient means of providing surveillance on a full time, all-weather basis and studies are currently being undertaken with a view to upgrading the platform based radar system utilising the latest technology available.

The present radar facility is supplemented by open radio links and support from Defence Force patrols. In addition to patrols undertaken by Navy surface craft, daily patrols are made by Tracker aircraft. Regular aerial patrols of the Australian Fishing Zone, which includes Bass Strait, are made through the area by RAAF P 3 Orion aircraft. When necessary these patrols can be supplemented by the producers' work boats and helicopters.

The package of measures that has been developed is considered adequate in the current circumstances in the Bass Strait petroleum producing fields. the package will be enhanced by the passage of the measures contained in the amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act now before the Parliament and by proposed upgrading of radar facilities. The effectiveness of the measures for the protection of the petroleum producing facilities is subjected to continuing review and, if additional measures are considered desirable, the Commonwealth will take steps to ensure they are introduced.
